one must opine, τὰ παραπλήσια Ph. 1.4; ὡς . . Epicur. Ep. 1p.23U.
one who forms opinions or conjectures, opp. κριτής, Antipho 5.94, cf. S.E. M. 7.157; opp. ἐπιστήμων, Pl. Tht. 208e.

children.label: II
children.definition: δοξασταί· δικασταί, Hsch.

forming opinions, conjecturing, opp. ἐπιστήμων, Pl. Tht. 207c; δ. ἐπιστήμη conjectural knowledge, Id. Sph. 233c, cf. 268c; δ. ἔννοιαι pertaining to judgement, Epicur. Sent. 24; τὰς δοξαστικὰς (sc. φαντασίας) belonging to opinion, Phld. Herc. 1003; τὸ δ. [μέρος τῆς ψυχῆς], opp. τὸ ἐπιστημονικόν, Arist. EN 1140b26.
original, full of ideas, ψυχὴ ἀνδρικὴ καὶ δ. Isoc. 13.17: τὸ -κόν Antig.Nic. ap. Heph.Astr. 2.18 [2.225].

children.label: II
children.definition: Adv. -κῶς, opp. κατʼ ἀλήθειαν, Arist. APr. 43b8, cf. Phld. Oec. p.14J., S.E. M. 11.156, Procl. in Prm. p.609 S.

matter of opinion, conjectural, opp. νοητός, Pl. R. 534a, Plu. Col. 2.1114c; opp. γνωστός, Pl. R. 478b, etc.; opp. ἐπιστητός, Arist. APo. 88b30; opp. ὁρατός, δ. θεός Plu. Amat. 2.756d; συλλαβὰς . . ἀληθεῖ δόξῃ δοξαστάς Pl. Tht. 202b; τροφὴ δοξαστή food of opinion, Id. Phdr. 248b. Adv. -τῶς S.E. M. 2.53.

children.label: II

Democr. 7.
clever at removing suspicion, Paul.Aeg. 2.12.
conceit of beauty, Pl. Phlb. 49d.

definition: δοξοκομπέω, = sq., Simp. in Epict. p.86 D. (s. v. l.).

thirst for fame or popularity, Phld. Lib. p.57O., Heraclit. Ep. 2, Plu. Per. 5, M.Ant. 11.18, Luc. Peregr. 2, App. BC 2.44, Hann. 9, etc.; δ. ἄκρατος Epicur. Fr. 120.
popularity-hunting, Apollon. ap. Stob. App. p.14 Gaisf.

laudation, Iamb. Myst. 2.10.
to be mad after fame, Ph. 1.550.
mad after fame, Chrysipp.Stoic. 3.167, Ph. 1.564, Iamb. VP 12.58.

would-be philosopher, Epigr. ap. Hegesand. 1.
one who imitates mere semblance (and not reality), Pl. Sph. 267e.
his art, Pl. Sph. 267e.
having the semblance of education, τέχνη Pl. Sph. 223b.
glorify, praise a god, PMag.Berol. 2.176.

children.label: II
children.definition: Pass., possess the power of judgement, τὸ τῶν ἀνθρώπων γένος δεδοξοποιημένον Plb. 18.15.16.
conceit of wisdom, Pl. Sph. 231b, Phlb. 49a, 49d, Plu. QPlat. 2.999f.
wise in oneʼs own conceit, Pl. Phdr. 275b; pretending to wisdom, Arist. Rh. 1387b32.
hunger after fame, Plb. 6.9.7.

skin when taken off, hide, of beasts, δ. αἰγῶν Thgn. 55; θηρῶν E. Cyc. 330, cf. Diog.Oen. 10; of birds, Hdt. 4.175; of men, Pl. Euthd. 285c; σατύρου Id. Smp. 221e; grape- skin, Ruf. Anat. 12.
skin on the living body, Ph. 2.100, Hld. 9.18.

EM 284.12; cf. δόρυ.

Aj. 211 (lyr.): — δορυάλωτος is a freq. v.l., as in Hp. Ep. 27, X. Cyr. 7.5.35, HG 5.2.5, Ph. 2.526, etc., cf. IG 14.1293.57.

definition: δορικμής, ῆτος, ὁ, ἡ, Ion. δουρ-,

spear-clashing, Pi. N. 3.60.

raging with the spear, A. Th. 687 (lyr.).

shaken by battle, αἰθήρ A. Th. 155 (lyr.).

Dim. of δορκάς, LXX Is. 13.14, Hsch. s.v. βούβαλος; silver ornament in that shape, IG 11(2).203 A 10 ( Delos, iii B. C.).
Hsch. δόρκαι· κονίδες, Id.
Call. Epigr. 33.2, AP 7.578 ( Agath.), Opp. C. 1.165; of a girl, AP 5.291.12 ( Agath.).

children.label: II
children.definition: δορκαλῖδες, ων, αἱ, = δορκάδειοι ἀστράγαλοι, Herod. 3.19.
quick-sightedly, accurately ( Crete), Hsch.

an animal of the deer kind (so called from its large bright eyes), in Greece, roe, Cervus capreolus, E. Ba. 699, X. Cyr. 1.4.7; in Syria and Africa, gazelle, Antilope dorcas, Hdt. 4.192 (in form ζορκάς), 7.69.—Other forms:— δόρξ, δορκός, ἡ, E. HF 376 (prob.), Call. Lav.Pall. 91, Luc. Am. 16: δόρκος, ὁ, Dsc. 2.75, Opp. C. 2.315, 3.3: δόρκων, ωνος, ὁ, Palamed. ap. Ath. 11.397a, LXX Ca. 2.17, Ar.Byz. Epit. 3.15: ζορκάς (v. supr.): ζόρξ, Call. Dian. 97, Fr. 239, Nic. Th. 42: ἴορκος, Opp. C. 2.296, 3.3. ( δόρκος and ἴορκος are distd. fr. δορκάς.)
of a deer, Theognost. Can. 185.29: δόρκιος, Edici. Diocl. 8.21.

tanning or currying hides, Man. 4.320.

food, a meal, Nic. Al. 166 (pl.).
supper-time, evening, Hp. Epid. 5.22, Ar. V. 103, X. An. 1.10.17: acc. to Philem. ap. Ath. 1.11d, some made it = ἄριστον.

the first day of the feast Apaturia, celebrated by public suppers in each phratria, personified in Philyll. 8.2: πρόπεμπτα τῆς Δ. IG 2.841b62; but τῆς ὁρτῆς τῇ δορπίῃ on the eve of the feast, Hdt. 2.48.
take an evening meal, Hsch.
belonging to the feast, ἁρμονίη Nonn. D. 12.148.

evening meal, Od. 12.439; taken at sunset, Il. 19.208, Od. 4.429, Pi. O. 10(11).47; ἄριστα, δεῖπνα, δόρπα θʼ αἱρεῖσθαι τρίτα A. Fr. 182.3, cf. Sch. Od. 2.20.—In later Ep., generally, meal, food, h.Ap. 511, A.R. 2.304, Q.S. 4.278, Opp. H. 1.26 (pl.); δόρποιο ποτοῦ θʼ ἅλις Orph. A. 406.

data.quote: ἄριστα, δεῖπνα, δόρπα θʼ αἱρεῖσθαι τρίτα

definition: δόρπος, ὁ, = foreg., Nic. Al. 66, AP 9.551 ( Antiphil.), Q.S. 9.431.

children.definition: offering supper, βωμός IG 12(5).244 ( Paros).

definition: δόρυ, τό, Att. gen. δόρατος, rare in Poets, as Ar. Ach. 1120, late Ep. dat. pl. δοράτεσσι Q.S. 6.363: Ep. and Ion. decl., gen. δούρατος (also in Pi. P. 4.38); dat. δούρατι (also in S. Ph. 721 (lyr.)); pl. δούρατα, δούρασι (but codd. of Hdt. usu. have δόρατα, δόρασι): more commonly δουρός, δουρί (but δορί Archil. 2.1); dual δοῦρε; pl. δοῦρα, δούρων, δούρεσσι; dat. pl. δούροις Opp. H. 3.573: Trag., gen. δορός; dat. δορί or δόρει, the former required by metre in A. Th. 347, 456, 958, Ag. 111, E. Hec. 909, Ph. 186, etc. (all lyr.), also in Id. Hec. 5; δόρει is required in S. OC 620, 1314, 1386; ξὺν δορὶ ξὺν ἀσπίδι Ar. V. 1081, but σὺν δόρει σὺν ἀσπίδι Achae. 29, cf. Choerob. in Theod. 1.346; δορί occurs in Prose in the phrases δορὶ ἑλεῖν, λαβεῖν (v. infr. II.2): nom. pl. δόρη E. Rh. 274, Theopomp.Com. 25; gen. δορῶν Hsch.: nom. δοῦρας AP 6.97 ( Antiphil.). Exc. sg. δόρυ, Hom. uses only the Ion. forms:

children.label: I
children.definition: stem, tree, οὔπω τοῖον ἀνήλυθεν ἐκ δόρυ γαίης Od. 6.167; but commonly, plank or beam, δοῦρʼ ἐλάτης κέρσαντες Il. 24.450; δούρατα μακρὰ ταμών Od. 5.162, cf. Il. 3.61; δούρατα πύργων 12.36; δούρατʼ ἀμάξης Hes. Op. 456; mostly of ships, δόρυ νήϊον shipʼs plank, Il. 15.410, etc.; νήϊα δοῦρα Od. 9.498; also, mast, E. Tr. 1148: hence,

data.quote: οὔπω τοῖον ἀνήλυθεν ἐκ δόρυ γαίης

children.definition: δ. εἰνάλιον, ἀμφῆρες, of a ship, Pi. P. 4.27, E. Cyc. 15; δ. ποντοπόρον S. Ph. 721 (lyr.); also δόρυ alone, A. Pers. 411, Ag. 1618, E. Hel. 1611; ἐπʼ Ἀργῴου δορός Id. Andr. 793; also δούρων, of oars, Hymn.Is. 152.
pillory, stocks, ἐν δουρὶ δεθεὶς αὐχένα Anacr. 21.9.

children.label: II
children.definition: shaft of a spear, δόρυ μείλινον the ashen shaft, Il. 5.666, al.: hence, generally, spear itself, δ. χάλκεον 13.247; ἀσπίδα καὶ δύο δοῦρε Od. 1.256, etc.; hunting-spear, Il. 12.303; δόρατα ναύμαχα boarding- pikes, Hdt. 7.89: freq. in military phrases, v. πέλεκυς I; εἰς δόρατος πληγήν within spearʼs throw, X. Eq. 8.10; εἰς δόρυ ἀφικόμενοι Id. HG 4.3.17; ἐπὶ δόρυ to the right hand, in which the spear was held, opp. ἐπʼ ἀσπίδα, Id. An. 4.3.29 (cf. κλίνω IV. 3, κλίσις III); παρὰ δόρυ Id. Lac. 11.10; εἰς δόρυ Id. HG 6.5.18; τὴν ἐμβολὴν ἐκ δόρατος ποιεῖσθαι Plb. 3.115.9:— ὑπὸ δόρυ πωλεῖσθαι, = Lat. sub hasta venire, D.H. 4.24, cf. Str. 4.6.7.

children.label: b
children.definition: pole of a standard, X. Cyr. 7.1.4.

children.label: c
children.definition: sceptre, E. Hec. 9.

children.label: d
children.definition: stick used as tourniquet, Hp. Nat.Puer. 24.

δουρὶ κτεατίζειν win wealth by the spear, i.e. in war, Il. 16.57; ὑπὸ δουρὶ πόλιν πέρθαι ib. 708; in Prose, δορὶ ἑλεῖν, λαβεῖν, Th. 1.128, App. BC 4.8; an armed force, συμμάχῳ δ. A. Eu. 773; δ. ἐπακτοῦ S. OC 1525; καὶ τὸ δ. καὶ τὸ κηρύκειον πέμπειν to offer war or peace, Plb. 4.52.4. (Cf. Skt. dá̄ru ‘piece of wood’, δορά (B), δρῦς.)
Hsch.
hurling spears, μηχάνημα J. AJ 9.10.3; δορυβόλον alone, Ph. Bel. 95.20.
Dim. of δόρυ, shaft of a hook or probe, Heliod. (?) ap. Orib. 47.17.5.
halbert, Pl. La. 183d; esp. a large kind used for cutting off halyards in sea-fights, Str. 4.4.1; in sieges, for pulling down battlements, Plb. 21.27.4.

definition: δορυθαρσής, ές, -δορίτολμος, Epigr.Gr. 1035.18 (Pergam.), APl. 16.170 (Hermodor.):— also δορυ-θρᾰσής, ές, Nonn. D. 17.100, 21.164, al.

definition: δορυκνίδιον, τό, Dim. of sq. 1, Gal. 11.864.

Nic. Al. 376 (cf. Sch.adloc.).

definition: δορύκρανος, δορύκτητος, δορύμᾰχος, v. δορίκρανος, δορίκτητος, δορίμαχος.

skilled with the spear, Hsch.

definition: δορυμόλπης ὁ προηγούμενος τοῦ θυομένου βοὸς τῷ Διί, Id.

spear-friend, i.e. war-friend, ally (wrongly expld. as ἐκ δορυαλώτου δ. προσαγορευόμενος by Plu. Aet.Gr. 2.295b), A. Ag. 880; ξένος τε καὶ δ. δόμων Id. Ch. 562, cf. S. El. 46, etc.: as Adj., δόμοι δορύξενοι A. Ch. 914; ἑστία S. OC 632.

definition: δορυξόος, ον, contr. δορυ-ξοῦς, ουν, ( ξέω)

compact of beams, νῆας A. Supp. 743 (lyr.):— Ion. δουροπ- Opp. H. 1.358.
with fiery spears, ἄστρων στρατός Lyr.Adesp. 128.

definition: δορυσσόητος, ον, = sq., μόχθων δορυσσοήτων of the toils

children.definition: of battle, S. Aj. 1188.

definition: δορυσσόος, ον, contr. δορυσ-σοῦς, οῦν (v. infr.): ( σεύω):—

children.definition: brandishing the lance, of persons, Hes. Sc. 54, A. Supp. 182, 985; πόνος δ. Thgn. 987: contr. -σοῦς S. OC 1313, A. Th. 125, prob. in E. Heracl. 774 (lyr.).
slaying with the spear, Ar. Fr. 196, Telecl. 29 (s. v. l.).

attend as a body-guard, τινά Hdt. 2.168, 3.127, Th. 1.130; τὸν ἔπαρχον PAmh. 2.79.52 (ii A.D.): generally, keep guard over, τὴν ἑκάστου σωτηρίαν D. 23.123:— Med., ψυχὴν λογισμῷ Them. Or. 1.5b:— Pass., to be guarded, στρατοπέδοις D. 17.12; δορυφορεῖσθαι τῇ τῶν πολιτῶν εὐνοίᾳ Isoc. 10.37: metaph., ὑπὸ μανίας Pl. R. 573a, cf. Ph. 2.239, al.

children.label: b
children.definition: attend, i.e. flank, the Sun, etc., Ptol. Tetr. 114, al., S.E. M. 5.38 ( Pass.).
attend as guard, ἡμῖν αὐτοῖς X. Cyr. 7.5.84; πειθαρχοῦντας αὐτῷ καὶ -φοροῦντας Plb. 32.8.6.
flank, Iamb. in Nic. p.77 P.:— Pass., ib. p.40P.

body-guard: used of the κωφὰ πρόσωπα or mute characters on the stage, Luc. Hist.Conscr. 4, Jul. Caes. 310c: hence of Aridaeus, who was put up as the successor of Alexander, ὁ δέ, ὥσπερ ἐπὶ σκηνῆς δ., κωφὸν ἦν ὄνομα βασιλείας Plu. An seni 2.791e, cf. Id. Alex. 77.

data.quote: ὁ δέ, ὥσπερ ἐπὶ σκηνῆς δ., κωφὸν ἦν ὄνομα βασιλείας

guard kept over, τῆς ἐπιστολῆς X. Cyr. 2.2.10: abs., Iamb. Myst. 2.7; concrete, body-guard, LXX 2 Ma. 3.28.

children.label: II
children.definition: κατὰ δορυφορίαν τῶν τροπικῶν κύκλων Placit. 2.23.6.
of or for the guard, οἴκησις Pl. Ti. 70b, Criti. 117c; δ. σημεῖα, = Lat. signa praetoria, standards of the praetorian guard, D.C. 60.35; τὸ δ. the guard, Id. 42.52.
spear-bearing, ὀπάονες A. Ch. 769.

children.definition: Subst., spearman, X. An. 5.2.4.
one of the body-guard of kings and tyrants, Hdt. 1.59, etc.; [ ὁ Περίανδρος] πρῶτος -φόρους ἔσχε Arist. Fr. 516.

mute character, Hsch., EM 284.21.
for plastering, PPetr. 3p.139 (iii B. C.).
plastering, PPetr. 3p.139.
Dim. of δόσις II 5, IG 14.956 A22.
to be inclined to give, Hsch.
liable to be surrendered as billets, PTeb. 5.176 (ii B. C.).

giving, φαρμάκου Antipho 1.18; χρημάτων Hdt. 1.61; μισθοῦ Th. 1.143; opp. αἴτησις, Pl. Euthphr. 14d; δ. χρημάτων καὶ λῆψις Arist. EN 1107b8; λήψεις καὶ δόσεις Arr. Epict. 2.9.12, cf. LXX Si. 41.19, Ep.Phil. 4.15.

children.label: b
children.definition: licence, permission, SIG 987.33 ( Chios, iv B. C.).
ἐμβολῶν δ. ramming in naval tactics, D.S. 13.10.

children.label: II
children.definition: gift, καί οἱ δ. ἔσσεται ἐσθλή Il. 10.213; δ. ὀλίγη τε φίλη τε Od. 6.208, 14.58, cf. Hdt. 1.90, 9.93, S. OT 1518, etc.; δόσιν κακὰν κακῶν κακοῖς A. Pers. 1041 (lyr.); θεῶν εἰς ἀνθρώπους Pl. Phlb. 16c.
bequest, legacy: κατὰ δόσιν by will (opp. κατὰ γένος, as heir-at-law), Is. 4.7, Isoc. 19.45, cf. Harp.
largess, = Lat. congiarium, Hdn. 6.8.8 (pl.).
contribution towards the fulfilment of a purpose, Chrysipp. (?) Stoic. 3.30.
payment on account, instalment, IG 1(2).296, 7.303.35 (Orop.), etc.; payment in kind, PMasp. 146.4 (vi A. D.), al.
portion, LXX Ge. 47.22, al., BGU 1122.12 (i B. C.); διελὼν εἰς δόσεις Plu. Arat. 13.
dose of medicine, Dsc. 2.171; δ. τελεία full dose, Ruf. ap. Orib. 8.57.5, etc., cf. Luc. Abd. 4.
τῆς οἰκονομίας πολλὴν ποιεῖσθαι δ. lay great stress on an arrangement, D.H. Dem. 51; οὐ τοσαύτην ποιούμενοι τῆς ἡδονῆς δ. ὅσην τῆς ἀληθείας ib. 18.
destiny, fate of an individual, ἡ ἀνθρωπίνη δ. Iamb. Myst. 1.3; esp. of planetary influence, Plot. 2.3.2, al.

definition: δόσκον, Ep. iterative of δίδωμι (q. v.).

children.definition: give-and-take, exchange, barter, Orph. Fr. 278 (pl.), Vett.Val. in Cat.Cod.Astr. 2.163.

definition: δότειρα, ἡ, fem. of δοτήρ, Hes. Op. 356, Nic. Al. 612.

children.definition: to be given, Hdt. 8.111.

children.label: II
children.definition: δοτέον one must give, Pl. R. 452e, Alex. 250, etc.; one must allow, c. inf., Luc. Abd. 9.

giver, dispenser, ταμίαι . . σίτοιο δοτῆρες Il. 19.44; ὀϊστοὶ θανάτοιο δ. Hes. Sc. 131; esp. of the gods, δ. εὐθηλέος ἥβης h.Hom. 8.9; μαντευμάτων Pi. Pae. 7.1; πυρὸς βροτοῖς δοτῆρα A. Pr. 612.—Poet. form used by X. Cyr. 8.1.9, and in later Prose, θεὸς δ. παντὸς ἀγαθοῦ D.H. 2.62, cf. J. AJ 1.18.6, Iamb. Myst. 3.31.

definition: δότης, ου, ὁ, later form of δοτήρ, LXX Pr. 22.8, 2 Ep.Cor. 9.7.

children.definition: inclined to give, giving freely, Arist. EN 1121b16. Adv. -κῶς Hsch. s.v. δοσείειν.

children.label: II
children.definition: ἡ -κή (sc. πτῶσις), the dative case, Stoic. 2.59, Str. 14.1.41, D.T. 636.4, A.D. Synt. 28.23, etc.
granted, LXX 1 Ki. 1.11, Ph. 1.273; that may or must be granted, Max.Tyr. 11.7.
= Lat. ducenarius, official receiving salary of 200,000 sesterces, IG 14.1347, POxy. 1711.4 (iii A. D.), etc.

children.label: II
children.definition: δουκηναρία, ἡ, assessment of 200,000 sesterces, ib. 1274.14 (iii A. D.).
= Lat. ducianus, Just. Edict. 13.2.
make a slave, treat as such, dub. in D.S. 12.24, cf. Arr. Epict. 3.24.76.
δ. τοὺς βίους Longin. 44.6, cf. Charito 2.7; τὸ σῶμα bring it into subjection, 1 Ep.Cor. 9.27.
enslavement, IG 9(1).39,42 ( Stiris), POxy. 38.10 (i A. D.).
enslaving, δ. θηρίον ἡ ἡδονή Plu. Volupt.Fr. 2 [117 Sandbach].
enticement of slaves from their master, Arist. EN 1131a7.

definition: δουλάριον, τό, Dim. of δούλη, Ar. Th. 537, Metag. 19, etc.; not used of male slaves, acc. to Luc. Lex. 25, but cf. Arr. Epict. 2.21.11.
δουλεία, ἡ, Ion. δουλ-ηΐη Anacr. 114, Hdt. 6.12: also δουλία Pi. P. 1.75:—

children.definition: slavery, bondage, ll. cc., A. Th. 253; δουλείας γάγγαμον, ζυγά, Id. Ag. 360 (anap.), S. Aj. 944 (lyr.); δ. καὶ ὑπηρεσία Ar. V. 602; ἡ τῶν κρεισσόνων δ. imposed by them, Th. 1.8; ἡ ὑπὸ τῶν βαρβάρων δ. Pl. R. 469c; applied to the condition of the subject allies of Athens, Th. 5.9.

children.label: II
children.definition: slaves, δουλεύοντα δουλείαις ἐμαῖς E. Ba. 803; ἢν . . ἡ δ. ἐπανιστῆται if the slave-class rise in rebellion, Th. 5.23; ἡ Ἡρακλεωτῶν δ. Pl. Lg. 776d; τὰς . . Εἱλωτείας καὶ Πενεστείας καὶ δουλείας Arist. Pol. 1264a36.

data.quote: τὰς . . Εἱλωτείας καὶ Πενεστείας καὶ δουλείας

children.label: III
children.definition: service for hire, μισθὸν δουλείας LXX 3 Ki. 5.6.

definition: δούλειος, α, ον, also ος, ον Pi. Fr. 223, E. Tr. 1330 (lyr.):—

children.definition: slavish, servile, εἶδος Od. 24.252; κεφαλή Thgn. 535; τύχα Pi. l.c.; δούλειον ἦμαρ E. Hec. 56, Andr. 99, cf. Tr. 1330; ζυγόν Pl. Lg. 770e; ἤθη ib. 790a.
a born slave, Seleuc. ap. Ath. 6.267c, D.S. 10 Fr. 1.
freedman, Vett.Val. 7.8, al.
δούλειος, δ. δεσμὰ γυναικῶν A.R. Fr. 12.13.
a service, E. Or. 221.

children.label: II
children.definition: a slave, S. Ant. 756, cf. E. Ion 748.
slavery, prob. f.l. for δούλωσις, Porph. Abst. 1.8.
one must be a slave, τινί E. Ph. 395, Ba. 366; οὐ μὴν δουλευτέον τοὺς νοῦν ἔχοντας τοῖς κακῶς φρονοῦσιν Isoc. 9.7.

data.quote: οὐ μὴν δουλευτέον τοὺς νοῦν ἔχοντας τοῖς κακῶς φρονοῦσιν

children.definition: servile, Al. Le. 23.7.
female attendant, Eust. 1661.47.
to be a slave, Hdt. 2.56, And. 1.138, Pl. Lg. 777d, etc.; παρά τινι D. 18.129: c. acc. cogn., δουλείαν δ. X. Mem. 3.12.2, Pl. Smp. 183a, al.

serve, be subject, τό τʼ ἄρχειν καὶ τὸ δ. δίχα A. Pr. 927, etc.; δ. ζεύγλαις ib. 463; τοῖς ἄρχουσι καὶ τοῖς νόμοις Pl. Lg. 698b; ἡδονῇ Id. Phdr. 238e, etc.; δ. γαστρί, ὕπνῳ, λαγνείᾳ, X. Mem. 1.6.8; κεναῖς δόξαις Polystr. p.29 W. [col. 20b Wilke]; τῇ γῇ δ. make oneself a slave to oneʼs land, i. e. give up rights that one may keep it, Th. 1.81; so δ. τῇ κτήσει αὐτοῦ Pl. R. 494d; δουλεύομεν δόξαισιν Philem. 93.8; δ. τῷ καιρῷ accommodate oneself to the occasion, AP 9.441 ( Pall.); θυμῷ Hdn. 1.17.6.

data.quote: τό τʼ ἄρχειν καὶ τὸ δ. δίχα

children.definition: render a service, τινά PLond. 5.1727.11 (vi A. D.).
Dim. of δουλίς, Hsch. s.v. θεράπνιον.

= sq. 1, ὅπλον X. Cyr. 7.4.15 ( Sup.); διακονήματα Pl. Tht. 175e; ἔργον Araros 18; δ. καὶ ταπεινὰ πράγματα ποιεῖν D. 57.45; -ώτεροι τὰ ἤθη Arist. Pol. 1285a20; δ. πόλεμος slave-war, Plu. Crass. 10. Adv. -κῶς Phryn.Com. 2D., X. Oec. 10.10: Comp. -ώτερον Arr. Epict. 4.1.25.
= sq. 2, παιδίον, σώματα, BGU 1120.10 (i B. C.), 26.23 (i A. D.).

definition: δούλιος, α, ον ( ος, ον AP 7.401 ( Crin.)),

children.definition: slavish, servile, in Hom. only δούλιον ἦμαρ the day of slavery, Il. 6.463, al., cf. IG 1(2).763; ἐσθῆτι δουλίῃ ( δουληΐῃ is f. l.) Hdt. 3.14; δ. ζυγόν Id. 7.8.γ, A. Ag. 953, Th. 471; δ. τροφή S. Aj. 499.

of a slave, δ. φρήν a slaveʼs mind, A. Ag. 1084 (lyr.); ἔργον (prob.) PGrenf. 2.78.11 (iv A. D.).—In a few places the Med. Ms. of A. gives δούλειος ( Th. 75, 471, 793), but the metre freq. requires δούλιος ( Pers. 50 (anap.), Ag. 953, 1041, al., so in S. Aj. 499), never δούλειος: in E., however, δούλειος is certainly required (v. sub v.). The common form in Att. Prose is δουλικός, and δοῦλος is used as Adj. in same sense.
Hyp. Fr. 235, AP 5.17 ( Rufin.), IG 14.1839.8: condemned by Poll. 3.74.

definition: δουλιχόεις, εσσα, εν, Ion. for δολιχόεις.

children.definition: eaten up by slaves, τὰ αὑτοῦ Philostr. VS 1.21.4.
Cat.Cod.Astr. 8(4).127.
of slavish mind, AB 393, Suid. s.v. ἀνδραποδώδεις.
teacher of slaves, title of play by Pherecr., cf. Ath. 6.262b; of Theodora, Procop. Arc. 15.
consorting with slaves, Paul.Al. O. 2.
to be ruled by slaves, D.C. 60.2; or, like slaves, Lib. Decl. 43.35.
slave-government, J. AJ 19.4.4.
servile war, Lyd. Ost. 34.
one who consorts with slaves, Tz. H. 6.466.
consorting with slaves, Tz. H. 6.467.
enslave, Herm. ap. Stob. 1.49.45.
enslaving, Sch. E. Or. 488.
bad like a slaveʼs, κόλυθρον Telecl. 3.
slavish spirit, Pl. Alc. 1.135c, Theopomp.Com. 87.

befitting a slave, servile, πόνος Hdt. 1.126; opp. ἐλευθέριος, X. Mem. 2.8.4 ( Comp.), cf. Pl. Grg. 485b, 518a, etc.: Sup., Phld. Herc. 1457.3. Adv. -πῶς, φθαρῆναι D.C. 61.15, cf. Gal. 17(2).146: Sup. -έστατα Cratin. 403.

definition: δοῦλος (A), Cret. δῶλος Leg.Gort. 1.1, al., ὁ:—prop.

children.definition: born bondman or slave, opp. one made a slave, τὰ ἀνδράποδα πάντα καὶ δοῦλα καὶ ἐλεύθερα Th. 8.28, cf. E. IA 330: then, generally, bondman, slave, opp. δεσπότης (q. v.): not in Hom., who twice has fem. δούλη, ἡ, bondwoman, Il. 3.409, Od. 4.12, cf. A. Ag. 1326, X. Cyr. 5.1.4, Pl. R. 395e, etc.: freq. of Persians and other nations subject to a despot, Hdt., etc.; οὔ τινος δοῦλοι κέκληνται, of the Greeks, A. Pers. 242: metaph., χρημάτων δ. slaves to money, E. Hec. 865; so γνάθου δ. Id. Fr. 282.5; τῶν αἰεὶ ἀτόπων Th. 3.38; λιχνειῶν, λαγνειῶν, X. Oec. 1.22, cf. Mem. 1.3.11.

data.quote: τὰ ἀνδράποδα πάντα καὶ δοῦλα καὶ ἐλεύθερα

children.label: II
children.definition: Adj. (not in A.), δοῦλος, η, ον, slavish, servile, subject, δ. πόλις S. OC 917, X. Mem. 4.2.29; γνώμαισι δούλαις S. Tr. 53; δ. ἔχειν βίον ib. 302; σῶμα δ., opp. νοῦς ἐλεύθερος, Id. Fr. 940; τοὺς τρόπους δούλους παρασχεῖν E. Supp. 877; δ. θάνατος, ζυγόν, πούς, Id. Or. 1170, Tr. 678, 507; δ. καὶ τυραννουμένη πόλις Pl. R. 577d; δ. ἡδοναί, = δουλοπρεπεῖς, ib. 587c, etc.: Comp. δουλότερος more enslaved, Αἴγυπτον δ. ποιεῖν Hdt. 7.7.
τὸ δ., = οἱ δοῦλοι, E. Ion 983, etc.; also, slavery, a slavish life, ib. 556 (troch.).
ancillary, δ. ἐπιστῆμαι Arist. Metaph. 996b11.

definition: δοῦλος (B) · ἡ οἰκία ἢ τὴν ἐπὶ τὸ αὐτὸ συνέλευσιν τῶν γυναικῶν, Hsch.; cf. δωλοδομεῖς, δωλέννετος.
δουλοσύνη, ἡ, poet. and Ion. for δουλεία,

children.definition: enslaved, τινί E. Hec. 448 (lyr.).
slave-like, slavish to look on, σῶμα J. BJ 2.7.2.

enslave, Hdt. 1.27; δουλοῖς καὶ σὲ καὶ πᾶσαν πόλιν A. Th. 254, cf. S. Tr. 467; δ. φρόνημα Th. 2.61:—mostly in Pass., to be enslaved, ὑπὸ Πέρσῃσι, ὑπὸ Ἁρπάγου, Hdt. 1.94, 174, cf. Th. 1.98; αἱ ψυχαὶ δεδούλωνται Hp. Aër. 23; δεδουλωμένοι τῇ γνώμῃ, τὴν γνώμην ἐδουλοῦντο, Th. 4.34, 7.71; ἐλεύθερος πᾶς ἑνὶ δεδούλωται, νόμῳ Men. 699, cf. Sam. 280:— Med. (with pf. δεδουλῶσθαι Th. 6.82), make subject to oneself, enslave, Id. 1.18, 5.29, 7.68, 75, Pl. Mx. 239d; τὸν ἥσσονα δουλούμεθʼ ἄνδρα E. Supp. 493; ἐπιθυμίαν Pl. Lg. 838d; τὸ ἑαυτοῦ θειότατον ὑπὸ τῷ ἀθεωτάτῳ . . δουλοῦται Id. R. 589e.

data.quote: δουλοῖς καὶ σὲ καὶ πᾶσαν πόλιν
τὸ ἑαυτοῦ θειότατον ὑπὸ τῷ ἀθεωτάτῳ . . δουλοῦται

children.definition: enslavement, Th. 3.10, Plu. Publ. 21, D.C. 53.7.
constraint, opp. τρυφή, Pl. Lg. 791d.
pertaining to service, πρᾶγμα Plu. Nob. 2.
= Lat. dux, PLond. 2.141.18 (iv A. D.), Just. Edict. 13.18 Intr., etc.

definition: δουπέω, fut. -ήσω AP 9.427 (s. v. l., Barb.): Ep. aor. δούπησα Il. 4.504, al.; also ἐγδούπησα (from γδουπέω) 11.45: pf. δέδουπα 23.679, Nic. Al. 15, A.R. 1.1304, Euph. 40; not freq. exc. in Ep.: ( δοῦπος):—

children.definition: sound heavy or dead; in Hom., of the heavy thud of a corpse, opp. the clashing of the armour, δούπησεν δὲ πεσών, ἀράβησε δὲ τεύχεʼ ἐπʼ αὐτῷ Il. 4.504, al.; ἢ αὐτὸς δουπῆσαι ἀμύνων λοιγὸν Ἀχαιοῖς 13.426; δεδουπότος Οἰδιπόδαο 23.679, cf. A.R. 1.1304, Euph. 40; δουπεῖ χεὶρ γυναικῶν falls with heavy sound upon their breasts, E. Alc. 104 (lyr.); of rowers, κώπῃ δουπεῖν dub. in AP 9.427 ( Barb.); of soldiers, strike heavily, ταῖς ἀσπίσι πρὸς τὰ δόρατα ἐδούπησαν X. An. 1.8.18; τοῖς δόρασι δ. πρὸς τὰς ἀσπίδας Arr. An. 1.6.4:— Pass., aor. δουπήθησαν AP 9.283 ( Crin.).—Rare in Prose, cf. Luc. Hist.Conscr. 22. (Said to be Cypr., AB 1095.)

data.quote: δούπησεν δὲ πεσών, ἀράβησε δὲ τεύχεʼ ἐπʼ αὐτῷ
ἢ αὐτὸς δουπῆσαι ἀμύνων λοιγὸν Ἀχαιοῖς
ταῖς ἀσπίσι πρὸς τὰ δόρατα ἐδούπησαν
τοῖς δόρασι δ. πρὸς τὰς ἀσπίδας

children.definition: clattering, χαλκός AP 4.3b.13 ( Agath.).

any dead, heavy sound, thud, δ. ἀκόντων Il. 11.364, 16.361; δ. ὀρώρει πύργων βαλλομένων 9.573, cf. 12.289; of the distant din of battle, 16.635; of the sound of footsteps, 10.354, Od. 16.10; of the measured tread of infantry, Il. 23.234, Hes. Th. 70; ὅμαδον καὶ δ., of a multitude, Od. 10.556; of the roar of the sea dashing against rocks or of a distant torrent, 5.401, Il. 4.455.—Rare in Trag., δ. μαράγνης A. Ch. 376 (lyr.); χερόπλακτοι δʼ ἐν στέρνοισι πεσοῦνται δοῦποι the loud beating of breasts, S. Aj. 634, cf. E. Ba. 513; ἀκούομεν πυλῶν δ. the noise of opening gates, Id. Ion 516. Rare in Prose, Th. 3.22 (v.l. ψόφον) ; θόρυβος καὶ δ. X. An. 2.2.19.

definition: δοῦρας, τό, a nom. sg. formed from the Homeric pl. δούρατα (v. sub δόρυ), AP 6.97 ( Antiphil.).

children.definition: of planks or beams of wood, ἵππος δ. the wooden horse, Od. 8.493, 512; ὀβελοί h.Merc. 121; πύργοι A.R. 2.381.
carved from wood, Lyc. 361.
E. Tr. 14, Pl. Tht. 184d.
a spearʼs throw off or distant, only neut. as Adv., Il. 10.357.
of a heavy spear, Wien.Stud. 25.3 ( Crete).
famed for the spear, Homeric epith. of heroes, Il. 5.55, Od. 15.52.

definition: δουρικλυτός, ον, = foreg., Il. 2.645, Od. 15.544, Archil. 3: dat. pl. δουρικλύτοις (sic) A. Pers. 85 (lyr.).
δουρικμής, δουρί-κτητος, δουρί-ληπτος, δουρι-μανής, δουρί-μαχος, Ion. for δορι-.

wood-splitting, σφῦρα AP 6.103 ( Phil.).

case or stand for spears, Od. 1.128.
one of the principal beams of the roof, Harp. s.v. στρωτήρ, EM 731.10.
δοριμανής, πόλεμος AP 9.553.

definition: δουροπαγής, ές, poet. for δορυπαγής, Opp. H. 1.358, Nonn. D. 4.230.

fit for holding, σκαφίδες Nic. Th. 618; κραδίην Id. Al. 21 (s. v. l., Sch. δοχεῖον).
holder, μέλανος δ. ink- horn, AP 6.66 ( Paul.Sil.), cf. 63 ( Damoch.), Gal. 14.719; τὸ θῆλυ ὥσπερ γονῆς τι δ. Luc. Am. 19.

receptacle, E. El. 828, Pl. Ti. 71c.

children.definition: reception, entertainment, Macho ap. Ath. 8.348f, LXX Ge. 21.8, al., PTeb. 112.89 (ii B. C.), Ev.Luc. 5.29, etc.; = ἄριστον, Hsch.

children.label: III
children.definition: σημεῖον ἐν θυτικῇ, Id.
receiving measure (officially prescribed for use by revenue officials), opp. ἀνηλωτικόν, PHib. 1.74 (iii B. C.), al., cf. PTeb. 11.6, PPar. 66.26, etc.

space contained in a handʼs breadth, Cratin. 350, Ar. Eq. 318, Com.Adesp. 571, Scyl. 112: expld. as, = παλαιστή, Sch. Ar. ad loc.; but also as, = σπιθαμή, Phot. s. h. v.; Hsch. and Suid. give both senses. (On the accent, v. Ael.Dion. Fr. 136, Poll. 2.157.)
use the dochmiac metre, Sch. E. Or. 140.
across, aslant, δόχμια . . ἦλθον Il. 23.116, cf. E. Or. 1261 (lyr.); δ. κέλευθον ἐμβάνειν Id. Alc. 1000 (lyr.), cf. 575 (lyr.); πέσε δ. A.R. 1.1169.

children.label: II
children.definition: ποὺς δ. the dochmiac measure, Choerob. in Heph. p.219 C.; ῥυθμὸς δ. Aristid.Quint. 1.17, Bacch. Harm. 100:—hence Adj. forms, δοχμιᾰκός Aristid.Quint. l.c.: δοχμικός, δοχμ-αϊκός, Sch. A. Th. 128, Sch. Ar. Av. 937. (Perh. cf. Skt. jihmá- ‘oblique’.)
with slanting, nodding plume, A. Th. 114 (lyr.).

turn sideways, δοχμωθείς, of a boar turning himself to whet his tusks or rip up his enemy, Hes. Sc. 389; of Hermes turning himself to dart through the keyhole, h.Merc. 146.—Later in aor. Act. δόχμωσε, Med. δοχμώσατο, Nonn. D. 42.193, 37.254.

definition: δοχμός, όν (Delph. ά, όν, v. infr.),

children.definition: δοχμὼ ἀΐσσοντε rushing on slantwise, Il. 12.148; δοχμοὶ μῆτραι lying obliquely, Hp. Mul. 2.141; δ. ἀπὸ προβολῆς κλινθείς Theoc. 22.120; δ. ἀνακρούων θηρὸς πάτον Nic. Th. 479; ἁ ὁδὸς ἁ δοχμά the cross-road, Klio 16.170 ( Delph., ii B. C.).

children.label: II
children.definition: συζυγία Sch. Ar. Ach. 283.
containing, able to hold, θερμοῦ καὶ ὑγροῦ Thphr. CP 2.4.11.

children.definition: Subst. δοχός, ὁ, receptacle, Hsch.; also, = λουτήρ, Id.
Arabian mustard, Lepidium Draba, Dsc. 2.157.
to be a watcher of a field or vineyard (cf. Mod. Gr. δραγάτης) , Ἀρχ.Ἐφ. 1913.27 (Thess.).

Supp. 27.11, subj. δρῶ, δρᾷς, δρᾷ, opt. δρῴην, Ep. δρώοιμι Od. 15.317; παρα-δρώωσι ib. 324: impf. ἔδρων: fut. δράσω: aor. 1 ἔδρᾱσα, Ion. ἔδρησα Thgn. 954: pf. δέδρᾱκα:— Pass., aor. 1 ἐδράσθην, δρασθείς, Th. 3.38, 6.53: pf. δέδρᾱμαι ( δεδρασμένων is f. l. in Id. 3.54):—

children.definition: do, accomplish, esp. do some great thing, good or bad (acc. to some δ. was the equiv. Dor. Verb for Att. πράττειν, Arist. Po. 1448b1), αἶψά κεν εὖ δρώοιμι μετὰ σφίσιν ἅσσʼ ἐθέλοιεν Od. 15.317 (where the Sch. interprets it διακονοίην, δουλεύοιμι I would serve . . , cf. δρήστης) ; ἄνδρες δραῖσιν ἀτάσθαλοι Alc. l.c.; opp. πάσχω, freq. in Trag., εὖ δρῶσαν, εὖ πάσχουσαν A. Eu. 868; ἄξια δράσας ἄξια πάσχων Id. Ag. 1527; κακῶς δράσαντες οὐκ ἐλάσσονα πάσχουσι Id. Pers. 813; of one in extreme perplexity, τί πάθω; τί δὲ δρῶ; Id. Th. 1062, cf. Ch. 899; δρῶν ἀντιπάσχω χρηστά S. Ph. 584; prov., " δράσαντι παθεῖν τριγέρων μῦθος τάδε φωνεῖ A. Ch. 313; δράσαντι γάρ τοι καὶ παθεῖν ὀφείλεται Id. Fr. 456, cf. S. OT 1272; τά γʼ ἔργα μου πεπονθότα . . μᾶλλον ἢ δεδρακότα acts of suffering rather than of doing, Id. OC 267; ὁ δρῶν the doer, whoever he be, A. Ag. 1359, etc.; ὁ δράσας the culprit, Pl. Lg. 879a, cf. S. Tr. 1108; ὁ δεδρακώς Id. OT 246, D. 23.40; used to avoid repetition of a verb, Th. 2.49, al.: c. dupl. acc., οἷʼ ἔργʼ ὁ παῖς μʼ ἔδρασεν S. Ph. 940, cf. OC 854, etc.: with Adv., εὖ, κακῶς δρᾶν τινά, do one a good or ill turn, Thgn. 108, S. Aj. 1154; δρᾶν τι εἴς τινα Id. OC 976; τί τινι Id. OT 1402; πάντα δρᾶν try every way, cj. in E. Hipp. 284; παντὸς εἶχε δρῶντος ἡδονήν was satisfied with the doing, S. OC 1604; τὰ δρώμενα what is doing or being done, ib. 1644, cf. D.C. 37.57: sg., τὸ δρώμενον S. El. 40, Th. 5.102; τί δράσω; to express helplessness or despair, S. Aj. 920, etc.; for οἶσθʼ οὖν ὃ δρᾶσον; v. οἶδα fin.

N. 2.9; ἀπὸ κρηνῶν μελιρρύτων δρεπόμενοι τὰ μέλη Pl. Ion 534b; στεφάνως δρεψεύμεναι Theoc. 18.40; κενεὰς ἐλπίδας ἐδρεπόμαν AP 12.125 ( Mel.); ἡδύσματα παρὰ τῆς ποιητικῆς Μούσης Jul. Or. 7.207c; ψυχὴν θείαν Orph. Fr. 228; αἷμα δρέψασθαι cull the fruits of murder, A. Th. 718, cf. Bion 1.22: abs., E. Hipp. 81: c. gen., κατὰ καιρὸν ἐρώτων δ. Pi. Fr. 123.1.

Tht. 173a; δ. καὶ δικανικός ib. 175d; δ. ἐν τῷ ἀποκρίνεσθαι Arist. Top. 156b37; λόγος δριμύτατος Id. SE 182b37 (but λέξις and λόγος δ. of striking turns of phrase, Hermog. Id. 1.2, 2.5): neut. as Adv., δριμὺ βλέπειν look bitter, Ar. Ra. 562; but also to look sharply, keenly, Pl. R. 519a, Luc. Symp. 16; ἐνορᾶν Id. Cat. 3, Ael. VH 14.22, D.C. 59.26:—regul. Adv. δριμέως, Anaxandr. 15.3; ἐρασθῆναι Ael. NA 7.15; δριμύτατα ἀλγεῖν Id. VH 12.1.
cause to smart, ὀφθαλμούς Alex.Trall.2:— Pass., οἱ δριμυττόμενοι τὰ βλέφαρα Aët. 7.15.

children.label: II

children.label: II

Fr. 495.4; δρομαίαν πτέρυγʼ ἐκτείνων Ar. Pax 160: in Prose, λαγὼς δ. a hare run by hounds, opp. εὐναῖος, X. Cyn. 5.9; ἴχνη δ., opp. εὐναῖα, the track of a running hare, ib. 3.8: metaph., δ. τῆς ψυχῆς ὁρμή Alcid. ap. Arist. Rh. 1406a23. Adv. -ως Sch. E. Or. 1416.

Aj. 889 (lyr.); ἅπαντι χρῆσθαι τῷ δρόμῳ at full speed, Luc. Dom. 10: of any quick movement, e. g. flight, A. Pers. 207: of Time, ἡμέρης δ. a dayʼs running, i. e. the distance one can go in a day, Hdt. 2.5; κατανύσαι τὸν προκείμενον δ. Id. 8.98; ἵππου δ. ἡμέρας D. 19.273: of Things, δ. νεφέλης, ἡλίου τε καὶ σελήνης, E. Ph. 163, Pl. Ax. 370b (pl.), etc.; οἱ δ. τῶν ἀστέρων Procl. Par.Ptol. 136; δρόμῳ at a run, freq. with Verbs of motion, δρόμῳ διαβάντας τὸν Ἀσωπόν Hdt. 9.59; ἰέναι Id. 3.77; χρῆσθαι Id. 6.112; χωρεῖν Th. 4.31; δ. ξυνῆψαν E. Ph. 1101; βοηθῆσαι δ. Ar. Fr. 551: in pl., δρόμοις A. Pr. 838, Supp. 819.

foot-race, as a contest, IG 2.594.11, al.: prov., περὶ τοῦ παντὸς δρόμον ( -μου codd.) θεῖν to run for oneʼs life, Hdt. 8.74; τὸν περὶ ψυχῆς δρόμον δραμεῖν Ar. V. 375; περὶ ψυχῆς ὁ δ. Pl. Tht. 173a: generally, contest, πλαγᾶν δρόμος, i. e. a pugilistic contest, Pi. I. 5(4).60.
lap in a race, S. El. 726 (interpol. ib. 691); ἐν τῷ δευτέρῳ δ. Arist. HA 579a8.
rapid delivery, Longin. Rh. p.312S.

SIG 463.14 ( Itanos, iii B. C.); δύʼ ἢ τρεῖς δρόμους περιεληλυθότε having taken two or three turns in the cloister, Pl. Euthd. l.c.; in Egypt, avenue of Sphinxes at entrance of temples, OGI 56.52 (Canopus, Ptol. III), Str. 17.1.28, etc.; δ. τοῦ ἱεροῦ BGU 1130.10 (i B. C.).

children.definition: props or shores upon which is laid the frame of a new ship, Od. 19.574, cf. Eust. et Sch. ad loc.; κατὰ δρυόχων ἐπάγη σανίς Epigr. ap. Moschion ap. Ath. 5.209c; ἐκ δρυόχων ναυπηγεῖσθαι to build a ship from the keel, Plb. 1.38.5; δρυόχους ἐπεβάλλετο νηός A.R. 1.723: metaph., δρυόχους τιθέναι δράματος ἀρχάς to lay the keel of a new play, Ar. Th. 52: οἷον ἐκ δρυόχων Pl. Ti. 81b, cf. Plu. Fort.Rom. 2.321e: sg. only in Poll. 1.85.

children.label: II
children.definition: woods, AP 6.16 ( Arch.): heterocl. pl. δρύοχα E. El. 1163 (lyr.).
woodpecker, Ar. Av. 304.

ripened on the tree, quite ripe, ἐλάα Chionid. 7, Eup. 312; αἱ δρυπεπεῖς (sc. ἰσχάδες) Ar. Lys. 564, Callias Com. 21: by a com. metaph., μᾶζαι δ. Cratin. 165, Telecl. 38; δ. ἑταῖραι Ar. Fr. 141: heterocl. acc. sg., τὴν ἁλίπαστον δρύπεπα, as Subst., AP 6.191 ( Longus):— δρυπετής or δρῠο-πέτης ( πίπτω), ready to fall, over-ripe, is a constant v. l., cf. Sch. Orib. 2p.746D., Hsch.
knot-wort, Drypis spinosa, Thphr. HP 1.10.6.

definition: δρυπολεῖ ταλαιπωρεῖ, ὀρειβατεῖ, πυρὶ πολιορκεῖ, Hsch.

children.definition: olive, AP 6.299 ( Phan.), Ath. 2.56a.
planted with olives, ἀγρός IG 9(1).61.20 ( Daulis).
Hsch.

definition: δρύπτω, E. El. 150: fut. δρύψω ( κατα-) v.l. in AP 5.42 ( Rufin.): aor. ἔδρυψα, Ep. δρύψα Il. 16.324:— Med., Hes. Sc. 243 ( κατα-, tm.), E. Hec. 655 (lyr.): aor. δρυψάμενος Od. 2.153:— Pass., AP 7.2 ( Antip. Sid.): plpf. δέδρυπτο Q.S. 14.391:—

children.definition: tear, strip, βραχίονα δουρὸς ἀκωκὴ δρύψʼ ἀπὸ μυώνων Il. l.c.:— Med., δρυψαμένω δʼ ὀνύχεσσι παρειὰς ἀμφί τε δειράς tearing each otherʼs cheeks and necks all round, Od. l.c.: mostly in sign of mourning, δρύπτεν κάρα E. El. 150 (lyr.); ἑκάτερθε παρειάς A.R. 3.672; also δρύπτεσθαι παρειάν to tear oneʼs cheek, E. Hec. 655; without παρειάν, X. Cyr. 3.1.13.

data.quote: βραχίονα δουρὸς ἀκωκὴ δρύψʼ ἀπὸ μυώνων

children.definition: τὴν δὲ χοῖρον αὐονὴ δρύπτει Herod. 8.2.—Poet., X. and later Prose, as Philostr. VA 3.38.

definition: δρῦς, ἡ (Pelop. ὁ, acc. to Sch. Ar. Nu. 401, cf. IG 9(1).485.5 ( Thyrrheum), but fem. in Arc., Schwyzer 664.23): gen. δρυός: acc. δρῦν ( δρύα Q.S. 3.280): nom. pl. δρύες Il. 12.132, A. Pr. 832, etc., δρῦς Thphr. CP 2.9.2, Paus. 8.12.1: acc. pl. δρῦς Ar. Eq. 528, Nu. 402, δρύας S. Fr. 403, Call. Del. 84, AP 7.8 ( Antip. Sid.): gen. δρυῶν Hdt. 7.218: dual δρύε Hdn.Gr. 1.420. [ ῠ, exc. in δρῦς, δρῦν: gen. δρῡός at the beginning of a verse, Hes. Op. 436]:—

children.definition: tree ( δρῦν ἐκάλουν οἱ παλαιοὶ . . πᾶν δένδρον Sch. Il. 11.86, cf. Hsch.); including various trees, Thphr. HP 3.8.2; esp. Quercus Aegilops ( φηγός) and Quercus Ilex ( πρῖνος), cf. ἡ φηγὸς καὶ ἡ πρῖνος εἴδη δρυός Dsc. 1.106; opp. πεύκη, Il. 11.494; opp. πίτυς, Od. 9.186, cf. Il. 13.389, 23.328, etc.; στέφανος δρυός crown of oak leaves, SIG 2588.7 ( Delos, ii B. C.); commonly, the oak, δ. ὑψικάρηνοι, ὑψίκομοι, Il. 12.132, 14.398, cf. 13.389, 23.328, etc.; sacred to Zeus, who gave his oracles from the oaks of Dodona, Od. 14.328; αἱ προσήγοροι δρύες A. Pr. 832; πολύγλωσσος δ. S. Tr. 1168, cf. Pl. Phdr. 275b: prov., οὐ γὰρ ἀπὸ δρυός ἐσσι . . οὐδʼ ἀπὸ πέτρης thou art no foundling from the woods or rocks, i. e. thou hast parents and a country, Od. 19.163, cf. Pl. Ap. 34d, R. 544d, AP 10.55 ( Pall.); but οὐ μέν πως νῦν ἔστιν ἀπὸ δρυὸς οὐδʼ ἀπὸ πέτρης . . ὀαρίζειν ʼtis no time now to talk at ease from tree or rock, like lovers, Il. 22.126; ἀλλὰ τί ἦ μοι ταῦτα περὶ δρῦν ἢ περὶ πέτρην; why all this about trees and rocks (i. e. things we have nothing to do with)? Hes. Th. 35; also διὰ πέτρας καὶ διὰ δρυὸς ὁρᾶν ‘to see through a brick wall’, Plu. Comm.not. 2.1083d.

data.quote: ἡ φηγὸς καὶ ἡ πρῖνος εἴδη δρυός

children.label: II
children.definition: Paus. 8.1.6), πίειρα δρῦς the resinous wood (of the pine), S. Tr. 766; of the olive, E. Cyc. 615 (lyr.); δ. θαλασσία, = ἁλίφλοιος, Ps.-Democr. Symp.Ant. p.5G.

children.label: III
children.definition: δ. ποντία, gulf-weed, Sargassum vulgare, Thphr. HP 4.6.9.

children.label: IV
children.definition: worn-out old man, AP 6.254 ( Myrin.), Artem. 2.25. (Cogn. with δόρυ; cf. Skt. dru- ‘wood’, in compds.)
PGrenf. 1.11.14 (ii B. C.).
wood-cutter, Il. 11.86, Theoc. 5.64, Philostr. Im. 2.33, al.; cf. δρυοτόμος. [δρῡ- Q.S. 9.163, 453, 13.56.]
nail-parings, Hsch.; also, = λῦπαι, ὀδύναι, i.e. lancinating pains or weals, bruises, Id.

definition: δρυφάζω, aor. inf. δρυφάξαι· δακεῖν, Hsch. δρυφαίνηκα· τὸν οὐ μέγαν ( Elean), Id.
δρύφακτος [ ῠ], ὁ, later τρύφακτος BCH 35.23 ( Delos, iv B. C.), OGI 598.3 ( Jerusalem), Hdn.Gr. 2.595:—

children.definition: railing or latticed partition, serving as the bar of the courts of law, the council-chamber, etc., Ar. V. 830 [corr. HD]: mostly in pl., ὑπερεπήδων τοὺς δ. Id. Eq. 675; ὑπὸ τοῖς δ. Id. V. 386; ἐπὶ τοῖς δ. ib. 552, X. HG 2.3.55: sg., δρυφάκτου τρόπῳ Apollod. Poliorc. 172.1.
hand-rail, Plb. 1.22.6, 10.
balcony, Arist. Ath. 50.2:—written δρύφρακτοι, Lib. Or. 11.217. (By dissim. for δρύ-φρακτος ( φράσσω), cf. Lib. l.c., Hellad. ap. Sch. Orib. 2p.746D., Sch. Ar. Eq. l.c.)
fence, fortify, Plb. 8.4.4.
enclosure, Str. 13.4.14.
fence round, guard by a fence, Lyc. 758 ( Pass.).

definition: δρύφειν περαίνειν, and δρυφόμενοι· φθειρόμενοι, Hsch.

children.definition: tearing, and δρυφοί, οἱ, scrapings, Hsch.: —also δρύφη, = κλάσματα, Id. s.v. πύρνα, cf. Suid.

definition: δρυφόροι, οἱ, religious guild at Thessalonica (cf. δενδροφόρος), BCH 38.41 ( δροι- lapis).

children.definition: bark: of a leaf, Parth. Fr. 26: δρύψαλα, Hsch.
= foreg., δ. τυρῶν AP 6.299 ( Phan.).
worn-out old man, and δρυψό-παις, παιδος, ὁ, ἡ, coquette, Hsch.; also, = ἐλεεινός, Id.
Hsch.

definition: δρωκτάζεις ( δροκτ- cod.): περιβλέπεις, Hsch.; cf. δρωπάζω, δρώπτω.
δρωμᾷ τρέχει, and δρωμίσσουσα· τρέχουσα, Hsch.

children.definition: gaze at, A.D. Adv. 139.8, Hsch.
apply a depilatory, δ. μέλιτι Orib. Eup. 4.7:— Med., Arr. Epict. 3.22.10, Hierocl. Facet. 64:— Pass., Luc. Demon. 50.
the application of a pitch-plaster, as a counter-irritant, Dsc. Ther. 3.
one must apply a pitch-plaster, Orib. Fr. 75.
depilator, Gloss.
serving as a counter-irritant, Gal. 18(2).894.
Phot.
pitch-plaster, Hp. Ep. 19 ( Hermes 53.71), Gal. 6.416, Dsc. Eup. 1.233, Archig. ap. Aët. 3.180:—also neut. pl. δρώπακα (sc. φάρμακα), Gal. 18(2).894. [ ᾰ in Lat. gen., Mart. 3.74, 10.65.]

definition: δρώψ ἄνθρωπος, Hsch. δύα, Dor. for δύη.

children.label: II
children.definition: δύαν· κρήνην, Id.
make into a dyad, in Pass., ἡ δυαδιζομένη μονάς Dam. Pr. 147.
of or for the number two, Plu. An.procr. 2.1025d; opp. μοναδικός, Dam. Pr. 119; δ. πᾶσα πρόοδος ib. 47. Adv. -κῶς Procl. in Prm. p.915 S., Herm. in Phdr. p.151A.
making into a dyad, Dam. Pr. 193.
express in the dual number, Eust. 47.28.
Pass., to be impressed with the sense of a thingʼs being double, see double, etc., S.E. M. 7.193.

children.label: II
children.definition: make into two, Ascl. in Metaph. 432.12 ( Pass.): — Pass., to be halved, of the moon, Theol.Ar. 12.
double, Theo Sm. p.29 H., Iamb. in Nic. p.60P.

children.label: III
children.definition: δυάζει· φλυαρεῖ, Hsch., Cyr. (cf. δρυάζω); also δυαεῖ Hsch.
twice, Ar. Fr. 769.
= Lat. duumviri, Wien.Stud. 24.288 ( Olbasa).
duumviralis, Wien.Stud. 24.289 ( Olbasa).

definition: δυανερικός, ή, όν, = foreg., CIG 3979 ( Antioch. Pisid.).

children.definition: the number two, Pl. Phd. 101c, Prm. 149c, Arist. Ph. 220a27, etc.
dyad, ἡ ἀόριστος δ. Arist. Metaph. 1081a14, Alex.Aphr. in Metaph. 58.12.
pair, Philostr. Im. 1.6, Lib. Or. 61.7.
plunge in misery, δυόωσιν . . ἀνθρώπους Od. 20.195:— Pass., pf. part. δεδυημένη Hsch.

definition: δυγός, Dor. for ζυγός, Schwyzer 180 ( Crete), 317 (Delph.), EM 316.57; Aeol., ib. 466.36; Boeot., Choerob. in Theod. 2.390.

children.definition: of the class of the dyad, μεσότης Dam. Pr. 189.
twice yearly, PAmh. 2.148.8 (V A.D.).
miserable, δυεροῦ θανάτοιο τυχεῖν IG 3.1337, cf. Max. 65, 182.

definition: δύη [ ῠ], ἡ, Dor. (not in Trag.) δύα, poet. Noun,

children.definition: misery, anguish, Od. 14.215, etc.; πῆμα δύης height of woe, ib. 338; πέλαγος ἀτηρᾶς δύης A. Pr. 746; γενναία δ. S. Aj. 938 (lyr.): pl., πημοναῖς δύαις τε A. Pr. 513, cf. 181 (lyr.), 525, etc.: also in late Prose, App. BC 4.42; Pythag. name for two (by false etym.), Theol.Ar. 12.
endure misery, Nonn. D. 26.113.
much-suffering, A.R. 4.1165, Opp. H. 2.436; painful, τοκετός Nonn. D. 41.411.
misery, A.R. 4.1395, APl. 16.113 ( Jul.), Hsch.:—written δῠη-πάθεια, EM 291.10.
h.Merc. 486.
dual, D.T. 635.30; τὸ δ. the dual number, A.D. Pron. 10.28, S.E. M. 1.142. Adv. -κῶς in the dual number, Phoeb. Fig. 1.4, Anon. in Tht. 73.4; = διττῶς, Suid.
A. Supp. 829 (lyr.).
POxy. 929.8, 15 (ii/iii A. D.).

definition: δύμεναι [ῡ], Ep. aor. 2 inf. Act. of δύω.

δύναμαι [ῠ], 2 sg. δύνασαι Il. 1.393, Od. 4.374, S. Aj. 1164 (anap.), Ar. Nu. 811 (lyr.), Pl. 574, X. An. 7.7.8, etc.; δύνῃ Carm.Aur. 19, also in codd. of S. Ph. 798, E. Hec. 253, Andr. 239, and later Prose, Plb. 7.11.5, Ael. VH 13.32; Aeol. and Dor. δύνᾳ Alc. Oxy. 1788 Fr. 15 ii 16, Theoc. 10.2, also S. Ph. 849 (lyr.), dub. in OT 696 (lyr.); δύνῃ is subj., Ar. Eq. 491, cf. Phryn. 337; Ion. 3 pl. δυνέαται Hdt. 2.142; subj. δύνωμαι, Ion. 2 sg. δύνηαι Il. 6.229 ( δυνεώμεθα -ωνται as vv.ll. in Hdt. 4.97, 7.163); also δύνᾱμαι Sapph. Supp. 3.3, GDI 4952 A 42 ( Crete): impf. 2 sg. ἐδύνω h.Merc. 405, X. An. 1.6.7; later ἐδύνασο Hp. Ep. 16 (v.l. ἠδ.), Luc. DMort. 19[9].1; Ion. 3 pl. ἐδυνέατο Hdt. 4.110, al. ( ἠδ- codd.): fut. δυνήσομαι Od. 16.238, etc.; Dor. δυνᾱσοῦμαι Archyt. 3; later δυνηθήσομαι D.C. 52.37: aor. ἐδυνησάμην Il. 14.33, Ep. δυν- 5.621; subj. δυνήσωνται Semon. 1.17, never in good Att., f. l. in D. 19.323: Pass. forms, Ep., Ion., Lyr., ἐδυνάσθην or δυνάσθην Il. 23.465, al., Hdt. 2.19, al., Pi. O. 1.56, Hp. Art. 48 (v.l. δυνηθείη), also in X. Mem. 1.2.24, An. 7.6.20; Trag. and Att. Prose ἐδυνήθην S. Aj. 1067, OT 1212 (lyr.), E. Ion 867 (anap.), D. 21.80,186: pf. δεδύνημαι D. 4.30, Din. 2.14, Phld. Rh. 1.261S.—The double augment ἠδυνάμην is Att. acc. to Moer. 175, but Ion. acc. to An.Ox. 2.374, and is found in codd. of Hdt. 4.110, al., Hp. Epid. 1.4.2 [1.26.βʹ], al.; ἠδύνω is required by metre in Philippid. 16; but is not found in Att. Inscrr. before 300 B.C., IG 2(2).678.12, al., cf. ἠδύνασθε ib. 7.2711 ( Acraeph., i A.D.); both forms occur in later writers: ἠδυνήθην occurs in A. Pr. 208, and codd. of Th. 4.33, Lys. 3.42, etc.: δύνομαι is a late form freq. in Pap. as UPZ 9 (ii B. C.), al. [ ῠ, exc. in δῡναμένοιο Od. 1.276, 11.414, Hom. Epigr. 15.1, and pr. n. Δῡναμένη, metri gr.]

children.label: I
children.definition: to be able, strong enough to do, c. inf. pres. et aor., Il. 19.163, 1.562, etc.: fut. inf. is f.l. ( πείσειν for πείθειν) in S. Ph. 1394, ( κωλύσειν for κωλῦσαι) Plb. 21.11.13, etc.: freq. abs., with inf. supplied from the context, εἰ δύνασαί γε if at least thou canst (sc. περισχέσθαι), Il. 1.393: also c. acc. Pron. or Adj., ὅσσον δύναμαι χερσίν τε ποσίν τε 20.360; [ Ζεὺς] δύναται ἅπαντα Od. 4.237; μέγα δυνάμενος very powerful, mighty, 1.276, cf. 11.414; δ. μέγιστον ξείνων Hdt. 9.9, etc.; μέγα δύναται, multum valet, A. Eu. 950 (lyr.); δ. Διὸς ἄγχιστα Id. Supp. 1035; οἱ δυνάμενοι men of power, rank, and influence, E. Or. 889, Th. 6.39, etc.; οἱ δυνάμενοι, opp. οἱ μὴ ἔχοντες, Democr. 255; opp. οἱ πένητες, Archyt. 3; δυνάμενος παρά τινι having influence with him, Hdt. 7.5, And. 4.26, etc.; δύνασθαι ἐν τοῖς πρώτοις Th. 4.105; δ. τοῖς χρήμασι, τῷ σώματι, Lys. 6.48, 24.4; ὁ δυνάμενος one that can maintain himself, Id. 24.12; of things, [ διαφέρει] οἷς δύνανται differ in their potentialities, Plot. 6.3.17.

data.quote: ὅσσον δύναμαι χερσίν τε ποσίν τε

children.definition: to be able, dare, bear to do a thing, mostly with neg., οὔτε τελευτὴν ποιῆσαι δύναται Od. 1.250; σε . . οὐ δύναμαι προλιπεῖν 13.331, cf. S. Ant. 455; οὐκέτι ἐδύνατο ἐν τῷ καθεστῶτι τρόπῳ βιοτεύειν Th. 1.130; οὐδὲ σθένειν τοσοῦτον ᾠόμην τὰ σὰ κηρύγμαθʼ ὥστε . . θεῶν νόμιμα δύνασθαι . . ὑπερδραμεῖν S. Ant. 455.

data.quote: οὐκέτι ἐδύνατο ἐν τῷ καθεστῶτι τρόπῳ βιοτεύειν
οὐδὲ σθένειν τοσοῦτον ᾠόμην τὰ σὰ κηρύγμαθʼ ὥστε . . θεῶν νόμιμα δύνασθαι . . ὑπερδραμεῖν

children.label: b
children.definition: enjoy a legal right, δ. τῆς γεωργίας ἀπηλλάχθαι POxy. 899.31 (ii/iii A.D.), etc.

ὡς and Sup., ὡς ἐδύναντο ἀδηλότατα as secretly as they could, Th. 7.50; ὡς δύναμαι μάλιστα κατατείνας as forcibly as I possibly can, Pl. R. 367b; ὡς δύναιτο κάλλιστον Id. Smp. 214c; ὡς ἂν δύνωμαι διὰ βραχυτάτων D. 27.3, etc.; simply ὡς ἐδύνατο in the best way he could, X. An. 2.6.2: with relat., ὅσους ἐδύνατο πλείστους ἀθροίσας Id. HG 2.2.9; λαβεῖν . . οὓς ἂν σοφωτάτους δύνωμαι Alex. 213.

children.label: II
children.definition: to be equivalent to, λόγοι ἔργα δυνάμενοι words that are as good as deeds, Th. 6.40: hence,
to be worth, c. acc., ὁ σίγλος δύναται ἑπτὰ ὀβολούς X. An. 1.5.6, cf. D. 34.23: abs., pass, be current, Luc. Luct. 10.
to be equal or equivalent to, τριηκόσιαι γενεαὶ δυνέαται μύρια ἔτεα Hdt. 2.142; δυνήσεται τὴν ὑποτείνουσαν will be equivalent to the hypotenuse, Arist. IA 709a19.

signify, mean, Hdt. 4.110, al.; τὸ πειρηθῆναι καὶ τὸ ποιεῖν ἴσον δύναται Id. 6.86.γʹ; δύναται ἴσον τῷ δρᾶν τὸ νοεῖν Ar. Fr. 691; δύναται τὸ νεοδαμῶδες ἤδη ἐλεύθερον εἶναι Th. 7.58: in later Greek, δύναται τὸ μνασθέντι ἀντὶ τοῦ μνασθέντος" is equivalent to . . , Sch. Pi. O. 7.110.

data.quote: τὸ πειρηθῆναι καὶ τὸ ποιεῖν ἴσον δύναται
δύναται ἴσον τῷ δρᾶν τὸ νοεῖν
δύναται τὸ νεοδαμῶδες ἤδη ἐλεύθερον εἶναι

children.label: b
children.definition: avail to produce, οὐδένα καιρὸν δύναται brings no advantage, E. Med. 128 (anap.), cf. Pl. Phlb. 23d.

children.label: c
children.definition: mean, ‘spell’, τὸ τριβώνιον τί δύναται; Ar. Pl. 842; αἱ ἀγγελίαι τοῦτο δύνανται they mean this much, Th. 6.36; τὴν αὐτὴν δ. δούλωσιν Id. 1.141, cf. Arist. Pol. 1313b25.

δύνασθαί τι to be equivalent when squared to a number or area, τοῖς ἐπιπέδοις ἃ δύνανται in the areas of which they [the lines] are the roots, Pl. Tht. 148b; ἡ ΒΓ τῆς Α μεῖζον δύναται τῇ ΔΖ the square on ΒΓ is greater than the square on A by the square on ΔΖ, Euc. 10.17; αἱ δυνάμεναι αὐτά [τὰ μεγέθη] the lines representing their square roots, ib. Def. 4, cf. Prop. 22; αὐξήσεις δυνάμεναί τε καὶ δυναστευόμεναι increments both in the roots and powers of numbers, Pl. R. 546b; τὴν ὑποτείνουσαν ταῖς περὶ τὴν ὀρθὴν ἴσον δυναμένην Plu. QConv. 2.720a, cf. Iamb. Comm.Math. 17; ἡ δυναμένη, Pythag. name for the hypotenuse of a right-angled triangle, Alex.Aphr. in Metaph. 75.31.

data.quote: τὴν ὑποτείνουσαν ταῖς περὶ τὴν ὀρθὴν ἴσον δυναμένην

children.label: b
children.definition: come to, Papp. 1.24, 27.

children.label: III
children.definition: οὐ δύναται, c. aor. inf., it cannot be, is not to be, τοῖσι Σπαρτιήτῃσι καλλιερῆσαι οὐκ ἐδύνατο Hdt. 7.134, cf. 9.45; δύναται it is possible, Plu. Virt.mor. 2.440e (s. v.l.).
potent, of drugs: hence as Subst., φυσικὰ δυναμερά, title of work by Ps.-Bolus, Suid. s.v. Βῶλος, cf. Archig. ap. Aët. 3.114.

powerful, efficacious, ἐρωτήματα Chrysipp.Stoic. 2.90 ( Comp.); τὸ τοῦ λόγου δ. Phld. Rh. 1.378 S. ( Sup.); λόγος, of a magicianʼs spell, Ps.-Callisth. 1.3; πρός τι Plb. 22.21.4, Onos. 12.2 ( Comp.); κατὰ τὴν σωματικὴν ἕξιν Plb. 36.16.3 ( Sup.); of wine, potent, Ath. 1.26b ( Sup.).
potential, τὸ δ., opp. τὸ ὑποστατικόν, τὸ ἐνεργητικόν, Dam. Pr. 61.

children.label: b
children.definition: expressing possibility, δ. σύνδεσμος (of κα) Sch. Theoc. 1.4.

definition: δύναμις [ ῠ], ἡ, gen. εως, Ion. ιος, Ion. dat. δυνάμι : ( δύναμαι):—

children.definition: power, might, in Hom., esp. of bodily strength, εἴ μοι δ. γε παρείη Od. 2.62, cf. Il. 8.294; οἵη ἐμὴ δ. καὶ χεῖρες Od. 20.237; ἡ δ. τῶν νέων Antipho 4.3.2, etc.: generally, strength, power, ability to do anything, πὰρ δύναμιν beyond oneʼs strength, Il. 13.787; in Prose, παρὰ δ. τολμηταί Th. 1.70, etc.; ὑπὲρ δ. D. 18.193; opp. κατὰ δ. as far as lies in one, Hdt. 3.142, etc. ( κὰδ δ. Hes. Op. 336); εἰς δύναμιν Cratin. 172, Pl. R. 458e, etc.; πρὸς τὴν δ. Id. Phdr. 231a.
outward power, influence, authority, A. Pers. 174 (anap.), Ag. 779 (lyr.); καταπαύσαντα τὴν Κύρου δ. Hdt. 1.90; δυνάμει προὔχοντες Th. 7.21, etc.; ἐν δ. εἶναι, γενέσθαι, X. HG 4.4.5, D. 13.29.

force for war, forces, δ. ἀνδρῶν Hdt. 5.100, cf. Pl. Mx. 240d, Plb. 1.41.2, LXX Ge. 21.22, OGI 139.8 (ii B. C.); μετὰ δυνάμεων ἱκανῶν Wilcken Chr. 10 (ii B. C.), etc.; δ. καὶ πεζὴ καὶ ἱππικὴ καὶ ναυτική X. An. 1.3.12; πέντε δυνάμεσι πεφρουρημένον, of the five projecting rows of sarissae in the phalanx, Ascl. Tact. 5.2, al.

data.quote: δ. καὶ πεζὴ καὶ ἱππικὴ καὶ ναυτική

children.definition: a power, quantity, χρημάτων δ. Hdt. 7.9.αʹ.
means, κατὰ δύναμιν Arist. EE 1243b12; opp. παρὰ δ., 2 Ep.Cor. 8.3; κατὰ δ. τῶν ὑπαρχόντων BGU 1051.17 (Aug.).

children.label: II
children.definition: power, faculty, capacity, αἱ ἀμφὶ τὸ σῶμα δ. Hp. VM 14; αἱ τοῦ σώματος δυνάμεις Pl. Tht. 185e; ἡ τῆς ὄψεως δ. Id. R. 532a; ἡ τῶν λεγόντων δ. D. 22.11: c. gen. rei, capacity for, τῶν ἔργων Arist. Pol. 1309a35; τοῦ λέγειν Id. Rh. 1362b22; τοῦ λόγου, τῶν λόγων, Men. 578, Alex. 94; δ. στρατηγική Plb. 1.84.6; δ. ἐν πραγματείᾳ Id. 2.56.5; δ. συνθετική D.H. Comp. 2: abs., any natural capacity or faculty, that may be improved and may be used for good or ill, Arist. Top. 126a37, cf. MM 1183b28.
elementary force, such as heat, cold, etc., Hp. VM 16, Arist. PA 646a14; ἡ τοῦ θερμοῦ δ. ib. 650a5; θερμαντικὴ δ. Epicur. Fr. 60, cf. Polystr. p.23 W.

children.label: b
children.definition: property, quality, ἰδίην δύναμιν καὶ φύσιν ἔχειν Hp. VM 13, cf. Nat.Hom. 5, Vict. 1.10; esp. of the natural properties of plants, etc., αἱ δ. τῶν φυομένων, τῶν σπερμάτων, X. Cyr. 8.8.14, Thphr. HP 8.11.1; productive power, τῆς γῆς X. Oec. 16.4; μετάλλων Id. Vect. 4.1: generally, function, faculty, δύναμις φυσική, ζωική, ψυχική, Gal. 10.635; περὶ φυσικῶν δ., title of work by Galen.

children.label: c
children.definition: agencies, ὑπάρχειν ἐν τῇ φύσει τὰς τοιαύτας δυνάμεις (sc. the gods) Polystr. p.10 W.

children.label: d
children.definition: function, meaning, of part in whole, Id. p.17 W.

children.label: e
children.definition: function, value, of a note in the scale, δ. ἐστι τάξις φθόγγου ἐν συστήματι Cleonid. Harm. 14, cf. Aristox. Harm. p.69M.; μέση κατὰ δύναμιν, opp. κατὰ θέσιν, Ptol. Harm. 2.5.

data.quote: δ. ἐστι τάξις φθόγγου ἐν συστήματι

children.definition: faculty, art, or craft, Pl. R. 532d, Arist. Metaph. 1018a30, EN 1094a10, Arr. Epict. 1.1.1; δ. σκεπτική the doctrine of the Sceptics, S.E. M. 7.1.
a medicine, Timostr. 7, etc.; δ. ἁπλαῖ Hp. Decent. 9, Aret. CD 1.4, etc.; δ. πολυφάρμακοι Plu. Pyth. 2.403c, Gal. 13.365: in pl., collection of formulae or prescriptions, Orib. 10.33.

children.label: b
children.definition: action of medicines, περὶ τῆς ἁπλῶν φαρμάκων δ., title of work by Galen; also, potency, δυνάμει θερμά, ψυχρά, Id. 1.672, al.
magically potent substance or object, PMag.Leid.V. 8.12: in pl., magical powers, Hld. 4.7.

children.label: III
children.definition: force or meaning of a word, Lys. 10.7, Pl. Cra. 394b, Diog.Oen. 12, Phld. Sign. 31, etc.

children.label: b
children.definition: value of sounds or letters, Plb. 10.47.8, D.H. Comp. 12, Luc. Jud.Voc. 5, etc.
worth or value of money, Th. 6.46, 2.97, Plu. Lyc. 9, Sol. 15.

children.label: IV
children.definition: capability of existing or acting, potentiality, opp. actuality ( ἐνέργεια), Arist. Metaph. 1047b31, 1051a5, etc.: hence δυνάμει as Adv., virtually, ὕστερον ὂν τῇ τάξει, πρότερον τῇ δυνάμει . . ἐστί D. 3.15; opp. ἐνεργείᾳ, Arist. APo. 86a28, al.; opp. ἐντελεχείᾳ, Id. Ph. 193b8, al.

data.quote: ὕστερον ὂν τῇ τάξει, πρότερον τῇ δυνάμει . . ἐστί

children.label: V
children.definition: power, κατὰ μεταφορὰν ἡ ἐν γεωμετρίᾳ λέγεται δ. Id. Metaph. 1019b33; usu. second power, square, κατὰ δύναμιν in square, Pl. Ti. 54b, cf. Theol.Ar. 11, etc.: chiefly in dat., [ εὐθεῖα] δυνάμει ἴση a line the square on which is equal to an area, ἡ BA ἐλάσσων ἐστὶν ἢ διπλασίων δυνάμει τῆς AK the square on BA is less than double of the square on AK, Archim. Sph.Cyl. 2.9: εὐθεῖαι δ. σύμμετροι commensurable in square, Euc. 10 Def. 2; ἡ δυνάμει δεκάς the series 12 + 22 . . . + 102, Theol.Ar. 64.

data.quote: κατὰ μεταφορὰν ἡ ἐν γεωμετρίᾳ λέγεται δ.

children.label: b
children.definition: square number, Pl. Ti. 32a.

children.label: c
children.definition: square of an unknown quantity ( x2), Dioph. Def. 2, al.
square root of a number which is not a perfect square, surd, opp. μῆκος, Pl. Tht. 147d.
product of two numbers, ἡ ἀμφοῖν (sc. τριάδος καὶ δυάδος) δ. ἑξάς Ph. 1.3, cf. Iamb. in Nic. p.108 P.; δυνάμει in product, Hero Metr. 1.15, Theol.Ar. 33.

children.label: VI
children.definition: powers, esp. of divine beings, αἱ δ. τῶν οὐρανῶν LXX Is. 34.4, cf. 1 Ep.Pet. 3.22, al., Ph. 1.587, Corp.Herm. 1.26, Porph. Abst. 2.34: sg., Act.Ap. 8.10, PMag.Par. 1.1275; πολυώνυμος δ., of God, Secund. Sent. 3.

children.label: VII
children.definition: manifestation of divine power, miracle, Ev.Matt. 11.21, al., Buresch Aus Lydien 113, etc.
square multiplied by square, fourth power, Hero Metr. 1.17; fourth power of unknown quantity (x⁴), Dioph. Def. 1 (pl.), al.: —hence δῠνᾰμο-δῠνᾰμοστόν, τό, the fraction 1/x⁴, Id. Def. 3, al.
square multiplied by cube, fifth power, Hippol. Haer. 1.2.10; fifth power of unknown quantity (x⁵), Dioph. Def. 1 (pl.), al.:—hence δῠνᾰμο-κῠβοστόν, τό, the fraction 1/x⁵, Id. Def. 3, al.
the fraction 1/x², Dioph. Def. 3, al.
strengthen, LXX Ec. 10.10, Thd. Da. 9.27, Polem. Call. 30, Porph. Sent. 35, Sall. 16.1, Procl. Inst. 70, al.:— Pass., Ep.Col. 1.11, etc.
put power into, σῶμα PMag.Leid.W. 7.16; πρᾶγμα ib. V. 8.19; τινά PMag.Par. 1.197:— Pass., PMag.Berol. 2.121.
strengthening, fortifying, invigoration, ψυχῆς Plot. 4.6.3.
strengthening, ἡ δύναμις τῶν πάντων -ώτατον (sc. αἴτιον) Dam. Pr. 61.
δύναμις, Pi. P. 4.238, B. 9.49, S. Ant. 604 (lyr.), 952 (lyr.), E. Ion 1012; ἐν (i.e. ἐς) δύνασιν pro virili parte, [to the utmost of one’s ability] IG 2(2).1126.5 (Amphict. Delph.).
power, lordship, domination, S. OT 593, D. 18.67; δ. ὀλίγων ἀνδρῶν Th. 3.62; πολιτικαὶ δ. the exercise of political power, Pl. Tht. 176c; οἱ τὰς δ. ἔχοντες Isoc. 2.8, cf. 9.19, Plb. 3.18.1.

children.label: II
children.definition: close oligarchy, opp. ἰσονομία, Th. 4.78, cf. And. 2.27, X. HG 5.4.46, etc.; ὑπὸ τῶν ὀλίγων δ. Pl. Plt. 291d; opp. πολιτεία, Arist. Pol. 1272b10; distd.fr. ὀλιγαρχία, ib. 1292b10, cf. 1293a31: in pl., of the Roman Senate, D.C. 52.1.

children.label: III
children.definition: mighty deeds, LXX 4 Ki. 13.12, al.

definition: δυνάστειρα, ἡ, fem. of δυνάστης, Tab.Defix.Aud. 38.11 ( Alexandria, iii A. D.).

children.definition: natural resources, τὰ δ. τοῦ Λιβάνου LXX 3 Ki. 2.46c.

arbitrary, ὀλιγαρχία Arist. Pol. 1298a32; oligarchical, αἵρεσις ib. 1306a18; ἰατρεία (opp. πολιτική) ib. 1272b3; πόλεις καὶ χῶραι Phld. Rh. 2.145 S.; λόγος Plu. Praec. 2.818a; tyrannical, δούλωσις Porph. Abst. 1.8.

hold power or lordship, be powerful or influential, Hdt. 9.2, Isoc. 12.82, OGI 56.12, etc.; τὸ -εῦον, opp. δῆμος, Th. 6.89; ἡ πόλις τῶν λοιπέων ἐδυνάστευε μέγιστον Hdt. 5.97: c. gen., to be lord over, Οἰχαλίας D.S. 4.31: metaph., αἱ ἄλογοι ἡδοναὶ δ. ψυχῆς Ph. 1.19: c. dat., Ath. 14.624d: generally, prevail, be prevalent, of a wind, of climate, Hp. Aph. 3.5, Aër. 12; to be influential, potent, ἐν τῷ σώματι Id. VM 16, cf. Herophil. ap. Gal. 12.619:— Pass., to be ruled, πρὸς μυρίων Ph. 2.503.

data.quote: ἡ πόλις τῶν λοιπέων ἐδυνάστευε μέγιστον

children.label: II
children.definition: Pass., to be concerned with powers of numbers, Pl. R. 546b.

lord, master, ruler, of Zeus, S. Ant. 608 (lyr.); ἄνδρες δ. the chief men in a state, Hdt. 2.32, cf. Pl. R. 473d, etc.; petty chief, princelet, Th. 7.33, etc.; ἡγεμόσι καὶ δ. καὶ βασιλεῦσιν Plb. 9.23.5, cf. 10.34.2, Posidon. 50 J., Str. 17.3.25; λαμπροὶ δυνάσται, of the stars, A. Ag. 6.
of or for a δυνάστης, arbitrary, Arist. Pol. 1320b31 ( Sup.): Comp., more potent, Gal. 6.396.

definition: δυνάστις, ιδος, ἡ, fem. of δυνάστης, Demetr. Eloc. 292; τύχη ἡ πάντων δ. ἀνθρώπων dub. in Phld. Mort. 24.[accent corr. HD]

children.definition: E. IA 280 (lyr.).
Phld. Sign. 11.
to be mighty, 2 Ep.Cor. 13.3.
δυνάστης, ὦ δυνάτα A. Pers. 674 (lyr., cod. Med.).

definition: δυνατός, ή, όν, also ός, όν Pi. N. 2.14, Apollon. Cit. 2:—

children.definition: strong, mighty, in body or mind, ὅ τι ἦν αὐτῶν δυνατώτατον the ablest-bodied men, Hdt. 9.31; sound in limb, opp. ἀδύνατος, Lys. 24.12; σῶμα δ. πρός τι X. Oec. 7.23; χερσὶ καὶ ψυχᾷ δ. Pi. N. 9.39; τοῖς σώμασι καὶ ταῖς ψυχαῖς X. Mem. 2.1.19; εἴς τι Pl. Hp.Mi. 366a; κατά τι ib. 366d ( Sup.): c. acc., ibid. ( Sup.); of ships, fit for service, Th. 7.60; of things, δυνατώτερον ἀδικία δικαιοσύνης Pl. R. 351a; λόγος a powerful argument, Epicur. Ep. 1p.31U.; δ. προτείχισμα Plb. 10.31.8.

inf., able to do, Hdt. 1.97, etc.; δ. λῦσαι mighty to loose, Pi. O. 10(11).9; λέγειν τε καὶ πράσσειν -ώτατος Th. 1.139, Pl. Prt. 319a; - ώτατοι καὶ τοῖς σώμασιν καὶ τοῖς χρήμασιν λῃτουργεῖν Decr. ap. Arist. Ath. 29.5; ἐᾶν τοὺς δ. ἄρχειν X. Ath. 1.3; ὅσονπερ δ. εἰμι, with inf. omitted, E. Or. 523.
powerful, influential, S. El. 219; τῶν Ἑλλήνων δυνατώτατοι Hdt. 1.53; οἱ δ. the chief men of rank and influence, Th. 2.65; χρήμασι δ. Id. 1.13, etc., cf. OGI 669.13 (i A. D.).
able to produce, productive, χώρα -ωτέρα εἰς τὴν καρπῶν ἔκφυσιν Gp. 2.21.5.
potential, Arist. Metaph. 1048a27.

children.label: II
children.definition: Pass., of things, possible, οὐ δύνατον γένεσθαι Sapph. Supp. 5.21, cf. Hdt. 9.111, A. Ag. 97 (lyr.), etc.; ὁδὸς δυνατὴ καὶ τοῖς ὑποζυγίοις πορεύεσθαι practicable, X. An. 4.1.24; λόγου δ. κατανοῆσαι Pl. Phd. 90c; βίον τοῖς πλείστοις κοινωνῆσαι δ. Arist. Pol. 1295a30; κατὰ τὸ δυνατόν, quantum fieri possit, Pl. Cra. 422d, D. 3.6, etc.; ἐς τὸ δ. Hdt. 3.24; εἰς ὅσον ἀνθρώπῳ δ. μάλιστα Pl. Phdr. 277a; ἐκ τῶν δυνατῶν X. An. 4.2.23; ἐπὶ τὸ δ. Id. Cyn. 5.8; ἐν δυνατῷ εἶναι BCH 29.172 ( Delos, ii B. C.); also ὅσον δυνατόν E. IA 997; ὅσον καθʼ ἡμᾶς δ. Id. Ba. 183; esp. with Sup., ὡς δ. πλεῖστον Isoc. 12.278; ὡς δ. κακίστους X. Mem. 4.5.5; γνώμη ὡς δ. δικαιοτάτη D. 24.13; τὰ δ. things which are practicable, Th. 5.89, cf. Arist. Rh. 1359b1.

children.label: III
children.definition: Adv. - τῶς strongly, powerfully, εἰπεῖν δ. Aeschin. 2.48: Sup. - ώτατα most ably, Pl. R. 516d.
δ. ἔχει it is possible, Hdt. 7.11.
to be more capable of financial burdens, τινός PFlor. 296.37 (vi A. D.).
potential, of the particle ἄν, κεν, A.D. Synt. 205.5, 265.15, cf. Sch. E. Or. 379.

definition: δύο [ῠ], also δύω in Ep., Eleg. and late, SIG 1231 (Nicomedia, iii/ iv A. D.), not in Ion. Inscrr. nor in Trag. ( δύο ῥοπάς shd. be read in E. Hel. 1090), nor in Att. Prose or Inscrr.: Lacon. acc. δύε IG 5(1).1; Thess. fem. δύας ib. 9(2).517: gen. and dat. δυοῖν Hp. Vict. 1.3, but f.l. in Hdt. 1.11, 91 [used as monos. in S. OT 640, cf. δώδεκα for δυώδ-]; later Att. also δυεῖν (esp. in fem. gen.) found in codd. of E. El. 536, cited fr. Th. by Ael.Dion. (?) Fr. 372, cf. 1.20 (cod. Laur.); Boeot. δουῖν Corinn. Supp. 2.54; later δυσί, δυσὶν ἡμέραις Th. 8.101 codd., δυσὶν ἡμέρῃσι v.l. in Hp. Acut.(Sp. ) 67; δυοῖν ὄμμασι καὶ δυσὶν ἀκοαῖς Arist. Pol. 1287b27, cf. Men. 699, SIG 344.26 ( Teos, iv B.C.), etc.: early Att. Inscrr. have δυοῖν IG 1(2).3.10, al., later δυεῖν SIG 2587.286, IG 2(2).463.78, al., from cent. iii on δυσί ib. 1028.27, al.; Ion. gen. δυῶν GDI 5653d9 ( Chios), Hdt. 1.94, 130, etc., dat. δυοῖσι ib. 32, 7.104; δυῶν also Dor., Leg.Gort. 1.40, Tab.Heracl. 1.139; δυοῖς Leg.Gort. 7.46.— Used indecl., like ἄμφω, by Hom. (who has no gen. or dat. δυοῖν) , τῶν δύο μοιράων Il. 10.253; δύω κανόνεσσι 13.407, etc.; so in Hdt. and Att., δύο νεῶν Hdt. 8.82; δύο ζεύγεσι Id. 3.130; δύο νεῶν Th. 3.89; δύο πλέθρων X. An. 3.4.9; with dual, δύο μναῖν dub. l. Id. Mem. 2.5.2; but not in Trag. and rare in Com., ἔτεσιν δύο Alex. 105; δύʼ ἔτεσιν Damox. 2.3: not in Att. Inscrr. before the Roman period, IG 3.1443, al.:—

children.definition: two, Il. 1.16, etc.; in Hom., δύο and δύω are sts. joined with plural Nouns, δύο δʼ ἄνδρες 18.498, al.; also in Trag., δύο κριούς S. Aj. 237 (lyr.); in Att. Prose, δύο τέχνας Pl. Grg. 464b; but δυοῖν is rare with plural Nouns, ὀρθοστάταις δυοῖν IG 2.1054.64; ἕνα καὶ δύο one or two, a few, Il. 2.346; δύʼ ἢ τρεῖς Ar. Pax 829, cf. X. HG 3.5.20; εἰς δύο two and two, Id. Cyr. 7.5.17; σὺν δύο two together, Il. 10.224, Hdt. 4.66; δύο ποιεῖν τὴν πόλιν to split the state into two, divide it, Arist. Pol. 1310a4.

definition: δυογόν, coined as etym. of ζυγόν, Pl. Cra. 418d.
δυοδεκάς, δῠο-δεκᾰδικός, v. δυω-. δῠοδεκαπλάσιος, = δωδ-, Bito 59.8. δῠοδεκᾰτημόριον, τό, = δωδεκ-, Paul.Al. K. 1. δυόδεκο, v. δυώδεκα.

children.definition: of two forms, double, dual, λόγος Porph. VP 50; τὸ δ. τῆς ψυχῆς Herm. in Phdr. p.167 A. Adv. -δῶς Dam. Pr. 55.
twelve, Il. 2.557, etc.
the Laws of the Twelve Tables, Lyd. Mag. 1.26,42.
zodiac, Vett.Val. 172.32.
S. Tr. 648 (lyr.).
twelfth, Hp. Morb. 3.16, Epid. 7.5.
seventy-second, SIG 1011.21 ( Chalcedon, iii/ii B. C.).
of two and twenty cubits, Eust. 644.39.
twenty-second, IG 1(2).212, Archim. Aren. 4.
fifty-second, Archim. Aren. 14.
two and a half, Supp.Epigr. 2.705 ( Perga).
making two, Arist. Metaph. 1083b36, Procl. in Prm. p.548S.
second, τὸ δ. (sc. μόριον) answering the question ποστημόριον, i.e. half, Sch. E. Hec. 32.
Democr. 136; δυοχῶσαι· πωμάσαι, Hsch.
diver, Call. Fr. 167, Opp. H. 2.436: as Adj., κηρύλος Lyc. 387; of persons, Id. 73.

duck, dive, ἠΰτε τις καύηξ δύπτῃσιν ἐς ἁλμυρὸν ὕδωρ Antim. Eleg. 6 (nisi leg. δύπτης) ; πρὸς κῦμα δυπτούσας Lyc. 715: without a Prep., ἔδυψε Νηρέως τάφους Id. 164; νειόθι δύψας A.R. 1.1326: c. acc., δύπτοντες κεφαλάς ib. 1008.

data.quote: ἠΰτε τις καύηξ δύπτῃσιν ἐς ἁλμυρὸν ὕδωρ

children.definition: un-, mis-, with notion of hard, bad, unlucky, etc., as δυσήλιος, δύσαγνος; destroying the good sense of a word, or increasing its bad sense: hence, joined even to words expressing negation, as δυσάμμορος, δυσανάσχετος; poet. in strong contrasts, as Πάρις Δύσπαρις, γάμος δύσγαμος. Before στ, σθ, σπ, σφ, σχ, the final ς was omitted, v. δυστ-. (Cf. Skt. duṣ-, dur-, e.g. durmanās, = δυσμενής; ONorse tor-, e.g. torsóttligr ( δύσμαχος); OIr. du-, do-, e.g. dochruth ‘misshapen’.)
messenger of ill, Nonn. D. 20.184.
to be impious, IG 14.432 ( Tauromenium).
impious, opp. εὐαγής, Man. 5.180, Poll. 1.33.
unchaste, A. Supp. 751 (lyr.), Orac. ap. Luc. Alex. 54.
have bad sport in fishing, Plu. Ant. 29.
unluckily caught, of fish, Opp. H. 3.272.
bad sport, Poll. 5.13.
hard to guide, D.H. 2.28, Luc. Abd. 3, 17; ἐπὶ τὸ καλόν D.H. 9.8; of horses, Hippiatr.Praef.
having seen hard service, Plu. Tim. 36.
impregnable, Poll. 3.141, 5.79, 105.
unhappy in oneʼs brothers, A. Th. 871 (lyr., Sup.), Vett.Val. 18.5.
laborious, Eust. 740.54.
badness of air, Str. 5.1.7, Cat.Cod.Astr. 2.161: pl., fogs, Str. 4.1.8.
having bad air, δεσμωτήριον (sc. ὁ κόσμος) D.Chr. 30.11; unwholesome, of the atmosphere, Procl. Par.Ptol. 122, cf. Sabin. ap. Orib. 9.20.8.
ill-blowing, stormy, ἀνέμοιο δυσαέος Il. 5.865; Ζεφύροιο δ. 23.200, al.: poet. gen. pl. δυσαήων for δυσαέων, Od. 13.99.
excessive, δ. κρυμός Call. Dian. 115; καῦμα Q.S. 13.134; κῦμα AP 7.739 ( Phaedim.).

children.label: II
children.definition: ill-smelling, of a seal, Opp. C. 3.114; φάρμακα Id. H. 4.662.
most miserable, τροφαί S. OC 330, LXX 3 Ma. 4.4.
most mournful, miserable, LXX 3 Ma. 6.31.
most melancholy, βοά A. Pers. 281 (lyr.).
not clear, murky, ὄρφνη E. Heracl. 857.
bleeding with difficulty, Aët. 8.44.
of ill fame, Orph. A. 1340.
riddle of woe, Sch. E. Ph. 45.
hard to take, impregnable, Poll. 1.170.
low degree of sensibility, Ti.Locr. 102e, Gal. 7.55 (pl.), prob. in Phld. Piet. 67.
to be hardly sensible, Alex.Trall. 1.13.
insensible, σώματα Alex.Aphr. Pr. 1.72, cf. Adam. 1.7; τὸ δυσαίσθητον, = ἀναισθησία, Gal. 4.784.

children.label: II
children.definition: Pass., scarcely perceptible, Alex.Aphr. in Sens. 85.24; hard to trace, Poll. 5.12.
hard to account for, Ph. 2.644, Gal. 13.605.
most miserable, Trag. only lyr., A. Th. 926 (prob.), S. OC 151; αἰὼν δ. a life that is no life, E. Hel. 213; δ. ὁ βίος Id. Supp. 960.
hard to heal, ἐκτρίμματα Hp. Fract. 29.
= foreg., Hsch. s.v. δυσηκῆ.
severe pain, Herod.Med. in Rh.Mus. 58.82.
very painful, A. Ag. 1165, Plu. Cons.Apoll. 2.106d, Q.S. 14.68.
hard to be borne, most painful, Eup. 410.

children.label: II
children.definition: unfeeling, hard-hearted, S. OT 12; δειλὸς ἢ δ. φρένας Id. Fr. 952.
= sq., Hp. Art. 41, Cass. Pr. 1 ( Comp.); τὸ τῆς φύσεως δ. Pl. Ax. 367b. Adv. -θῶς Philum. ap. Orib. 45.29.36.
deadly, Nic. Al. 12, 157, Luc. Dem.Enc. 13: neut. pl. as Adv., Q.S. 12.408.
hard to cure, inveterate, Q.S. 9.388 (- άλθετος Hsch.).

definition: δυσάλιος [ ᾱ], ον, Dor. for δυσήλιος.

children.definition: hard to alter, Gal. Protr. 11; hard to digest, Hp. Alim. 49; χυμός Alex.Aphr. Pr. 1.83.
hard to escape, Nic. Al. 251, 537, LXX Wi. 17.17, Man. 3.247.
hard to catch or take, ἄγρα Pl. Ly. 206a ( Comp.); of birds and fish, Arist. HA 615a17, 599b25; ἐρύματα Ph. 2.133.

hard to conquer, ἀρχά A. Pr. 167 (lyr.); πάθος Luc. Abd. 18 ( Sup.); immune, τοῖς ἔξωθεν αἰτίοις δ. σῶμα Gal. 4.742; πρὸς νόσους Sor. 1.32 ( Comp.): c. gen., δ. κακῶν beyond reach of ills, S. OC 1723 (lyr.).
hard to comprehend, Pl. Ti. 51a ( Sup.).
making unfortunate mistakes, Vett.Val. 11.16.
δυσανάβατος, πέτραι Simon. 58.2.
hard to climb, Corn. ND 14.
hard to read, prob. for δύσγνωστος, Plb. 3.32.1.
hard to throw up, ὑγρά Dsc. 1.1, cf. Androm. ap. Gal. 13.28.
hard to assimilate, Diph.Siph. ap. Ath. 3.91e, Gal. 19.364, Hippiatr. 1.
hard to evaporate, Artem. 1.1.
hard to cleanse, ἕλκωσις Gal. ap. Orib. Syn. 9.3.8.
hard to call back, Plu. Adul. 2.74e; J. BJ 2.18.8 (but simply, hard to summon, call together, Plu. Thes. 24), etc.
hard to restore, of hysterics, Sor. 2.29 ( Comp.), cf. Herod.Med. in Rh.Mus. 58.74; or to good spirits, Max.Tyr. 33.6. Adv. - τως, ἔχειν to be hard to restore to oneʼs senses, Dsc. Alex. 16.
hard to carry upwards, ψυχή Plu. Rom. 28:—poet. δυσαγκόμιστος, hard to recall, αἷμα A. Eu. 262 (lyr.).
hard to mix or temper, κοινωνία Plu. An.procr. 2.1024d.
hard to determine: poet. δῠσάγκρῐτος, πόνοι A. Supp. 126 (lyr.).
hard to recover, μνήμη Alcid. Soph. 19.

children.label: II
children.definition: hard to recover from, ἀρρωστία Jul. Or. 6.181a. Adv. - λήπτως, ἔχειν to be in a bad way for recovery, Ruf. ap. Orib. 8.47.4.
unable to return to ordinary habits, Ath.Med. ap. Orib. inc. 1.6.
difficult convalescence, Vett.Val. 236.17.
hard to analyse, Porph. in Cat. 132.9. Adv. - τως Simp. in Cat. 212.16.
hard to destroy, consume, στοιχεῖον Ph. 2.505.
restless, Eust. 1296.58.
hard to convince, Pl. Prm. 135a.
hard to sail up, ὁ Ῥοδανός Str. 4.1.14.
offensive to inhalation, Arist. Sens. 443b12.
transpiring with difficulty, Gal. 7.287.
hard to pass, Ph. 1.672, 2.118.
hard to restore, Alex.Trall. Febr. 7.
hardly recovering from an illness, Hp. Alim. 28.
bear ill, Th. 7.71; to be greatly vexed, ἐπί τινι, πρός τι, Plu. Cam. 35, Plb. 16.12.5; περί τινος Phalar. Ep. 37; τοῖς γενομένοις J. AJ 13.16.2: abs., Eus.Mynd. 59, Aët. 8.44.
hard to bear, intolerable, ὕβρεις Ph. 2.92; κήδη Phleg. Macr. 4, cf. Dsc. Eup. 1.235, Porph. Abst. 3.20: poet. δῠσ-άνσχετος A.R. 2.272.

children.label: II

want of men, App. BC 1.7.
X. Mem. 2.2.8, cf. Gal. 7.181. Adv. - τως Poll. 3.130.

definition: δυσάνεμος [ ᾱ], ον, Dor. for δυσήνεμος, S. Ant. 591 (lyr.).

soon vexed, ill to please, Antipho Soph. 89, Critias Fr. 42 D., Men. 803 (but better - ήνιον (q.v.)); opp. εὔθυμος, Arist. Phgn. 805b6; vexed, annoyed, in Comp. - ιώτερος Phld. Acad.Ind. p.50 M.
much vexing, Plu. Cons.Apoll. 2.106d.
hard to open, πυξίδες Diog. Ep. 50.

definition: δυσάνολβος, ον, strengthd. for ἄνολβος, Emp. 124.

children.label: II
children.definition: = δυσάντητος II, κύματα ib. 6.310, cf. Musae. 324.

disagreeable to meet, boding of ill, opp. εὐάντητος, Luc. Tim. 5, etc.

hard to gainsay, D.H. 5.18: metaph., ἐπιθυμία J. AJ 18.9.5.
Hsch., EM 406.7. Adv. δῠσαντιρρή-τως Plb. 9.31.7.

inexorable, Sch. S. OT 334.
hard to wipe out, Sch. S. Tr. 682.

Cat. 10a4: c. gen., - ότεραι τῶν ἐμβρύων having difficulty in bringing forth, Id. HA 587b1; δ. ἀπὸ λόγου a person hard to draw away from . . , Pl. Tht. 195c. Adv. - τως, ἔχειν τινός Eust. 1389.46, cf. Eustr. in EN 140.18.
Eust. 1054.30, Suid.

hard to demonstrate, Pl. R. 488a.
hard to unlearn, J. AJ 16.2.4.
hard to drive away, Sch. Theoc. 10.11.
hard to render or define, S.E. M. 7.242, Bacch. Harm. 95.
hard to put aside, πάθος Olymp. in Alc. p.101 C.
difficulty of recovering, mortal sickness, Erot. s.v. δυσθεσίην.
hard to restore, M.Ant. 11.8, Gal. 14.792.

children.label: II
children.definition: hard to recover from, ὀργαί Phld. Ir. p.63 W.
with difficulty in bending, Herod.Med. in Rh.Mus. 58.90.
hard to answer, Luc. Vit.Auct. 22. Adv. - τως, ἔχειν, of a letter, Mithr. Ep. 1.

children.label: II
children.definition: Act., hardly answering, Paul.Aeg. 3.9.
hard to catch, Alex.Aphr. in Sens. 26.18; irreparable, Gloss.

hard to get free of, δ. πάθος τὸ φιλότιμον Olymp. in Alc. p.51 C. Adv. - τως Erot. s.v. βλακεύειν, Gal. 8.284.

children.label: II

children.label: II
children.definition: to be displeasing to, Id. 7.5.6, D.S. 18.62; τῷ θεῷ Ph. 2.6:—also Med. -ουμένη φιλία Plu. Mult. 2.94d, cf. Iamb. VP 35.255.
malaise, distress, Antyll. ap. Stob. 4.37.15, Sor. 1.26.
distress, Pl. Ax. 366d; dissatisfaction, τινί or ἐπί τινι, Plb. 4.21.7, 23.7.5.

distressing, σύμπτωμα Herod.Med. ap. Orib. 6.20.21.

Mem. 3.13.3 ( Comp.), Diph. 63, Nicostr. 31 ( Comp.), Plu. Sanit. 2.128d; ἀνοίας νόσημα δυσάρεστον Polystr. Herc. 1520.1; τὸ δ. displeasure, Plu. Sol. 25. Adv. - τως, ἔχειν πρός τι Id. Tranq. 2.476b.

most painful, πάθος A. Eu. 145 (lyr.).

= foreg., Hdt. 8.100, Onos. 10.26; δ. ταῖς ἐλπίσιν Plu. Tim. 34:— Med., to be melancholy, angry, Democr. 286, E. Med. 91.
despondency, despair, Hp. VM 10, Pl. Lg. 666b, etc.; πρὶν ἐλθεῖν ξυμμάχοις δυσθυμίαν E. Supp. 696: pl., Id. Med. 691, S. Fr. 663, Arist. Pr. 954b35, Ph. 2.99.

melancholy, Arist. Phgn. 813a33.

to be hard to heal, Paul.Aeg. 3.18.

hardly perspiring, Thphr. Sud. 18.
to have bad omens in a sacrifice, Plu. Caes. 63, 2.587c.
dipped in the sea, AP 6.38 ( Phil.).
with scanty secretions, Hp. Mul. 1.34; δ. πάθος Orib. Fr. 78.

definition: δυσίμερος [ ῑ], ον, κάματος, πῆμα, of the

Ag. 826; περὶ δύσιν Πλειάδος Damox. 2.19; δ. χειμερινή, θερινή, ἰσημερινή, Cleom. 1.9; δ. τροπική Str. 2.4.7; ἄχρι ἡλίου δύσεως IG 4.597 ( Argos); ἁλίου ἄχρι δ. ib. 606 (ibid.); Κυνὸς ψυχρὰν δ. S. Fr. 432.11; personified, PMag.Berol. 2.94: pl., δύσιες, opp. ἀντολαί, A.R. 1.85: metaph., δ. τοῦ λογισμοῦ Ph. 1.511.
quarter in which the sun sets, west, πρὸς ἡλίου δύσιν Th. 2.96; πρὸς δύσεις Arist. Mu. 393a18; ἀπὸ δύσεως CIG 1755 ( Opus); πρὸς δύσει Plb. 1.42.5; πρὸς τὰς δύσεις βλέπειν Id. 5.104.7.

children.definition: hiding-place, Opp. H. 1.330.
hard to track, Sch. S. Aj. 32.
not easily rusted in Comp., Orib. 49.3.5.

hard to overthrow, Ph. 1.61; στάσις J. BJ 2.17.4.
hard to purify, Ph. 1.239, al.; hard to purge, πνεύματα Plu. Bruta anim. 2.991b, cf. Dsc. 5.69.

children.label: II

hard to hold in, ἵπποι X. Mem. 4.1.3 ( Sup.); πλήθη Plu. Num. 4: metaph., Corn. ND 30; πλοῦτος Luc. Tim. 29 (s.v.l., al. δυσκάτοχος); hard to keep in mind, retain, Plu. Pyth. 2.408b.
hard to go down into, σπήλαιον Conon 35.1.
hard to bend, Plu. QConv. 2.650d, Aret. SD 2.3: Comp., Sabin. ap. Orib. 9.19.2.
= foreg., Cass. Pr. 61, Sch. Ar. Th. 74. Adv. - τως, ἔχειν Aët. 16.8.
noisome from smoke, δώματα A. Ag. 774 (lyr.).

hard to endure, Ph. 2.73, Plu. Phoc. 4, etc. Adv. - τως Porph. Marc. 8, Herod.Med. ap. Aët. 9.2.
making a landing difficult, βράχη Stad. 114.
hard to overcome, Plb. 15.15.8, D.H. 3.7; hard to refute, Id. Rh. 8.3; τὸ δ. impregnability, Corn. ND 20.

hard to break, Thphr. HP 3.7.4, Dsc. 3.22, Apollod. Poliorc. 139.8.
hard to comprehend, D.S. 1.3, Ph. 2.216, M.Ant. 5.10.
hard to reconcile, Plu. Lib.educ. 2.13d, Ath. 14.625b.
hard to bring to an end, πόλεμοι Str. 14.1.28; hard to overthrow, δυναστεία J. BJ 4.5.5.
hard to learn or understand, Isoc. 10.11, Pl. Plt. 303d ( Comp.), D.H. Th. 9. Adv. -μαθήτως, ἔχειν Isoc. 2.33.
hard to overcome, D.S. 3.35; νόσος (sc. πενία) Lib. Decl. 34.4.
hard to understand, διάλεκτος D.S. 5.14, cf. Plu. Aud. 2.47c.
hard to check, ἄλγος A. Ch. 470 (lyr.); βοή LXX 3 Ma. 5.7; of persons, Plu. Alex. 31; restless, ψυχή E. Med. 109 (anap.); τὸ -ότερον Thphr. Vent. 35.
hard to digest, Thphr. CP 1.14.4.
hard to keep in awe, Plb. 1.67.4.
hard to conquer, D.S. 2.48.
hard to execute, M.Ant. 6.19, Arr. Epict. 3.12.8; hard to digest, Sor. 2.32.
difficulty of swallowing, Herod.Med. in Rh.Mus. 58.86, Philum. ap. Aët. 8.48.
have difficulty in swallowing, Herod.Med. ap. Orib. 5.30.12.
hard to swallow, Arist. Sens. 443b12, Archig. ap. Gal. 12.976.
hard to effect, X. Cyr. 8.7.12 ( Comp.).
hard to place rightly, ἐν τῇ ἐπιβάσει, of stallions, Hippiatr. 14.
hard to extinguish, D.S. 4.54, Plu. Def.orac. 2.417b.
hard to restore or rally, X. Cyr. 5.3.43 ( Comp.).
not to be despised, X. Cyr. 8.1.42 ( Comp.).
indigestion, Anon.Lond. 6.10.
hard to work, λίθος Str. 17.1.33; καρποὶ -ότεροι slower to mature, Thphr. CP 1.14.4; hard of digestion, Dsc. 2.93, Ph. 2.244.

children.label: II
children.definition: X. Mem. 4.2.7 ( Comp.).

children.label: III
children.definition: hard to tame, γένος ταύρων Agatharch. 76 ( Sup.); hard to overcome, Luc. Tyr. 15.
hard to succeed in, ἔργον Demetr. Eloc. 127, Ph. 2.83, Gal. UP 15.7; τυραννίς Chio Ep. 15 ( Comp.).

children.label: II

hard to cicatrize, Dsc. 5.81; ἕλκη Apollon. Mir. 42.
hard to burn, Apollod. Poliorc. 139.8.
ill-sounding, shrieking, φόβος Il. 16.357; ζῆλος δ. envy with its tongue of malice, Hes. Op. 196; δ. ὕμνος Ἐρινύος A. Th. 867 (anap.), cf. Fr. 451 I; μοῦσα E. Ion 1098 (lyr.).
hard to excrete, Gal. 18(1).580 ( Sup.).
hard to temper, φύσις πρὸς τὸ πιθανὸν δ. Plu. Dio 52; δύσμικτα καὶ δ. Id. Amat. 2.754c.
with ill gains, ill-gotten, Opp. H. 2.417.
full of misery, δυσκηδέα νύκτα φυλάσσω Od. 5.466.

children.label: II

past remedy, A. Eu. 825 (cf. Sch.adloc.): but perh. rather formed by analogy from εὔκηλος: hence, spiteful.
difficulty of moving, Hp. Aph. 3.17, Arist. GA 780a25, PA 685a8.
move with difficulty, Herod.Med. in Rh.Mus. 58.104.
hard to move, Pl. Ti. 56a, Ph. 2.227 ( Comp.), Thphr. Vent. 35 ( Sup.); πλοῖα Plb. 1.22.3. Adv. - τως, ἔχειν πρὸς τοὺς ἀνέμους Arist. Cael. 294b17.

children.label: II
children.definition: δ. πρὸς τοὺς φόβους Pl. R. 503d; δ. ὑπὸ ὀργῆς Arist. VV 1250a5; δ. ποιεῖν τὴν διάνοιαν Id. PA 686a30; ἕξις -οτέρα διαθέσεως Id. Cat. 9a10; τὸ -ον obstinacy, Phld. Lib. p.55 O.; of language, clumsiness, τὸ ἄσχημον καὶ δ. Id. Po. 994.35. Adv. -τως καὶ δυσμαθῶς ἔχειν Pl. R. 503d.
firm, resolute, Plu. Thes. 36; inexorable, Ἅιδης AP 7.221.
impervious to motion, of the soul, Plot. 1.4.8.

inglorious, Il. 9.22 (poet. acc. δυσκλέᾰ for δυσκλεέα); infamous, shameful, of persons and things, δ. θέα A. Pr. 243; δυσκλεεστάτῳ μόρῳ Id. Pers. 444; πρῶτον μὲν οὐκ οὖσʼ ἄδικός εἰμι δυσκλεής E. Hel. 270. cf. X. Cyr. 3.3.53, LXX 3 Ma. 3.23 ( Sup.). Adv. - εῶς S. El. 1006, E. Hel. 993 codd., Plu. Superst. 2.169a.

children.definition: ill-fame, infamy, S. Fr. 188, E. Med. 218, Th. 3.58, Pl. Lg. 663a, etc.; ἐπὶ δυσκλείᾳ tending to disgrace them, S. Aj. 143 (anap.).

children.label: II
children.definition: ingloriousness, D. 60.24.
of ill name, boding ill, Luc. Am. 39.
to be unlucky in oneʼs lot, esp. in standing for an office, opp. λαγχάνω, Pl. Lg. 690c.
piece of ill luck, Plb. 30.20.9 (pl.); τῆς πατρίδος D.S. 32.22 (pl.).
unlucky, Phryn. PS p.61 B.

definition: δυσκλής, poet. for δυσκλεής, Simm. Secur. 6.

hard to inflect, irregular, δ. ῥήματα, title of work by Eulogius, EM 809.33.
ill-famed, Hsch.
bad for the bowels, Dsc. 1.105, Plu. Sanit. 2.137a.
costive, Paul.Aeg. 1.44.
unsocial, Pl. R. 486b; ἀρχή Plu. Demetr. 3.
to have bad nights, Hp. VM 10, Acut. 30.
making bed unpleasant, Aristaenet. 2.7.

discontent, peevishness, Ar. V. 106, Pl. R. 411c.

hard to glue together, Gal. 11.124, 133; ill-glued or fastened, loose, Luc. Hist.Conscr. 11.

making bed uneasy, μέριμνα Ar. Nu. 420.

hard to please, discontented, fretful, peevish, Ar. V. 942; γῆρας E. Ba. 1251; δ. ψυχὴ καὶ ἀγρία Pl. Lg. 649e, cf. Arist. EN 1108a30, etc.; τὸ δ. Pl. Lg. 791c; of animals, intractable, Id. Tht. 174d ( Comp.): so in Adv. δυσκόλως, ἔχειν, διακεῖσθαι πρός τινα, D. 19.132, Isoc. 3.33; δυσκολώτερον διακεῖσθαι Pl. Phd. 84e.

children.label: II
children.definition: troublesome, harassing, δ. ἡ ἡνιόχησις Id. Phdr. 246b; πυρετοί Hp. Coac. 38: generally, unpleasant, ἄν τι δ. συμβῇ D. 18.189, cf. Men. 89; εἴ τι δ. πέπρακται Θηβαίοις πρὸς ἡμᾶς D. 18.176; καιροὶ δ. difficult times, IG 2(2).682.33. Adv. - λως, ὑπακούειν Hp. Epid. 3.8.

hard to bear, intolerable, πότμος S. Ant. 1346 (lyr.); τέκνα E. HF 1422.
hard to bake, ἄρτος EM 150.35.
hard to bruise, Damocr. ap. Gal. 13.636.
intemperate, Opp. H. 2.517.
bad temperament, of the air, Str. 6.4.1, Plu. Alex. 58 (pl.); σώματος Stoic. 3.216; τῶν ἐν ἡμῖν δυνάμεων Ph. 1.29. ( δυσκρᾰσίη Man. 4.543.)
= sq., δυσκρατέστατον πάντων ὁ λόγος Stob. 3.33.10.
hard to control, τὸ δ. τῆς ἐπιβολῆς D.S. 3.3; ungovernable, ill-disciplined, J. AJ 19.4.1; γηρῶντι ἤδη δ. εἶναι (sc. τὴν ἀρχήν) App. Syr. 61.

hard to distinguish, Plu. Fac.lun. 2.922a; = sq., Aët. 5.10.

Aph. 3.8; but δύσκριτα ἐγένετο there was an obscure crisis, Id. Epid. 3.12; δ. ἐστι πότερον . . ἢ . . difficult of solution, Id. Aph. 1.12, Pl. R. 433c. Adv. - τως doubtfully, darkly, A. Pr. 662; δ. ἔχειν to be in doubt, Ar. Ra. 1433.

hard to come by, πραγματεία Plb. 3.32.1; τἀγαθόν Phld. Herc. 1251.4 (dub.).

rolling with difficulty, δ. ἔχειν Philostr.Jun. Im. 10.

to be hard of hearing, Gal. 12.653, AP 7.731 ( Leon.), Dsc. 4.162.
deafness, Dsc. Eup. 1.61.
hard of hearing, Hp. Coac. 193, Arist. Insomn. 459b21, LXX Ex. 4.11, Str. 14.2.21; τὸ τοῦ γήρως δ. Plu. Lib.educ. 2.13e.
hard to pound or bray, Archig. ap. Aët. 3.184.

rough-husked, κάρυον Nic. Al. 271.
Hsch.
hard to take hold of, Sor. 1.88; hard to catch, μοχθηρία Ph. 2.366, cf. Luc. Anach. 27; hard to comprehend, Str. 13.4.12, A.D. Synt. 225.28, Plu. Aud.poet. 2.17d.
A. Pers. 448.
hard to compute, Anaximen. ap. Stob. 2.8.17, Plu. Sollert. 2.981e, Gal. 18(2).631, D.C. 73.15.

children.label: II
children.definition: impatient of the yoke, ἡμίονοι Ael. NA 16.9. Adv. - φως, φέρειν E. Tr. 303.
indissoluble, δυσλύτοις χαλκεύμασι A. Pr. 19; ἄκος τῶν δ. πόνων E. Andr. 121 (lyr.); ὦμοι stiff, Arist. Phgn. 811a4. Adv. - τως, ἔχειν X. Oec. 8.13.

to be slow at recognizing, A. Ch. 225.
hard to learn, A. Ag. 1255; δ. ἰδεῖν hard to know at sight, E. Med. 1196; τὸ δ. difficulty of knowing, Id. IT 478.

slowness at learning, Pl. R. 618d (pl.), Lg. 812e, etc.:—written δυσ-μάθεια, Id. Ep. 315c, Iamb. VP 20.95.
Hsch.; title of play by Pratinas, Ath. 9.392f.
hard to soften, Ruf. ap. Orib. 8.24.22.
thick, ὕδατα Thphr. HP 7.5.2.
unfading, Trag.Adesp. 339.

one must fight a losing battle with, ἀνάγκῃ δʼ οὐχὶ δ. S. Ant. 1106.

hard to fight with, unconquerable, X. HG 4.2.10 ( Comp.), E. Hec. 1055 ( Sup.); πάντων -ώτατον γυνή Id. Fr. 544; of things, A. Pr. 921, Pl. Lg. 863b, D. 1.4, etc.
difficult, δ. κρῖναι A. Ag. 1561 (lyr.).

children.definition: unsocial: Adv. - τως, ἔχειν Plu. QConv. 2.640d.
hard to appease, Plu. Art. 19; πικρία Id. Vind. 2.553a.

ill-will, enmity, ἡ ἐκ σοῦ δ. S. El. 619; ἐν δ. εἶναι ib. 1124; δ. ἄρασθαί τινι E. Heracl. 991: in Prose, Democr. 191, Antipho 4.1.3, etc.; φθόνος καὶ δ. Isoc. 5.68, Pl. R. 500c; φθόνοι καὶ ἄλλαι δ. Id. Prt. 316d.

hostile, ἄνδρες δ. Il. 5.488; δυσμενέες enemies, 16.521, cf. Schwyzer 84.12; δυσμενέων ὄχλος A. Th. 234 (lyr.), cf. 366 (lyr.), Hdt. 3.82, S. Aj. 662 ( Sup.), etc.; οἱ ὑμέτεροι δ. X. HG 5.2.33: c. dat., τῷ πατοῦντι δυσμενεῖς A. Ag. 1193, cf. S. Ph. 585; οὐδὲν τυράννου -έστερον πόλει E. Supp. 429: less freq. c. gen., ἄνδρα δ. χθονός an enemy of the land, S. Ant. 187, cf. Ph. 2.136. Adv. -νῶς Pl. Tht. 168b; δ. ἔχειν τινί Isoc. 3.5; πρὸς τὴν πόλιν Id. 14.6:—poet. δυσμενέως, Nonn. D. 21.85 (v.l.).

definition: δυσμενίδης, ου, ὁ, = foreg., Ael. VH 3.7.

difficulty of alteration, Sor. 1.91.
hard to alter, Hp. Alim. 51, Plu. Frig. 2.952c.

hard to break or move, Sch. S. OT 12.

hard to traverse, πέλαγος Philostr. VA 4.15.

Phd. 61e; ἐπὶ δυσμῇσιν ἐών at the point of setting, Hdt. 3.104; περὶ ἡλίου δυσμάς Lys. 1.39; ἥλιος ἦν ἤδη περὶ δυσμάς Hell.Oxy. 15.5: metaph., τὸ γῆρας δυσμαὶ βίου Arist. Po. 1457b25, cf. D.H. 4.79, Ph. 1.678, S.E. M. 9.90, Diog.Oen. 2, etc.

children.label: II

wrathful, θεός Poll. 1.39; χόλος AP 9.69 ( Parmenion).
= foreg., δένδρεα AP 7.141 ( Antiphil.); ψυχαί Ptol. Tetr. 159 (- ίτας).

definition: δυσμήτηρ, ερος, ἡ, in Od. 23.97 μῆτερ ἐμὴ δύσμητερ my mother

contriving ill, Suid., Hsch. (cod. - ήτης).

definition: δυσμήτωρ Dor. δυσ-μάτωρ, ορος, ὁ, ἡ, in A. Supp. 67 (lyr.) δ. κότος

children.definition: an ill motherʼs wrath.
to be at loss how to do, c. inf., A. Ag. 1360.
hard to effect, Epimen. ap. D.L. 1.113; difficult, Ἀρχύτεω δυσμήχανα ἔργα κυλίνδρων Eratosth. Fr. 35.7; prob. f.l. for δύσμαχον, J. BJ 4.1.2.

children.label: II

hard to remember, Arist. Rh. 1416b22, Aen.Tact. 24.2, Epicur. Ep. 2p.35U., D.S. 1.3.

to be ill-affected, τινί LXX 3 Ma. 3.24, Plu. Cic. 38.
hard to be understood, Darius ap. D.L. 9.13, 2 Ep.Pet. 3.16; χρησμοί Luc. Alex. 54.
