children.definition: hard to rein, unbridled, Gal. 19.94 (s.v. δυσήνιος).
thankless, τῶν πυκνῶν φιλημάτων A. Fr. 135.

definition: δυσχειμερινός, ή, όν, = sq., τὰ δ.

children.definition: wintry climates, Thphr. HP 8.8.1.
wintry or stormy, Hom. (only in Il.) epith. of Dodona, 2.750, al.; χώρη Hdt. 4.28, cf. Arist. HA 606b5; φάραγξ A. Pr. 15: metaph., δ. πέλαγος δύης ib. 746; δ. ἆται Id. Ch. 271.

children.label: II
children.definition: bearing winter ill, Arist. HA 596b5, Gp. 19.2.8.

definition: δυσχείμων, ον, gen. ονος, = foreg. 1, A.R. 4.635.

children.definition: a hard conquest, incorrect formation in S. Ant. 126.
hard to subdue, Hdt. 7.9.βʹ ( Sup.), D. 61.37, Plu. Alc. 4, D.C. 53.25 ( Comp.): Sup. δυσχειρότατον is prob. f. l. in D.S. 5.34.
with disgust, v.l. in Arist. Rh. 1408a17.

definition: δυσχεραίνω, impf. ἐδυσχέραινον Pl. Tht. 169d: aor. ἐδυσχέρᾱνα S. OC 1282, Isoc. 12.201: aor. Pass. ἐδυσχεράνθην Plu. Praec. 2.820f: ( δυσχερής):—

children.definition: to be unable to endure or put up with, to be disgusted at, c. acc., Isoc. 14.46, Pl. Tht. 195c, D. 19.116, etc.; θεούς Pl. Lg. 900a; δ. τὸ γενέσθαι τι X. HG 7.4.2; τὸ ἀδικεῖν Pl. R. 362b: c. acc. et part., to be annoyed at his doing, Aeschin. 1.158.

feel dislike, disgust or annoyance, to be displeased, περί τινος And. 3.35; τινί at a thing, D. 55.11; ἐπί τινι Isoc. 1.26; πρός τι D.H. Th. 34, Plu. Pyrrh. 21; κατά τινος Luc. Nav. 10; also δ. ἑαυτῷ to have misgivings, Arist. Metaph. 984a29:— Pass., to be hateful, ὄνομα δυσχεραινόμενον Plu. Publ. 1; δ. ὑπὸ πολλῶν Id. Cic. 24.

inf., scorn to do a thing, Pl. R. 388a: c. acc., δ. τι τῶν λεχθέντων feel qualms about, Id. Plt. 294a; ταῦτʼ οὐκ ἐδυσχέραινεν felt no scruple about, Aeschin. 1.54; to be fastidious, περὶ τὰ μαθήματα Pl. R. 475b.

children.label: II
children.definition: cause annoyance, ῥήματʼ ἢ τέρψαντά τι ἢ δυσχεράναντʼ S. OC 1282; δ. τὴν ὁδόν make it difficult, App. Ill. 18:— Pass., to be disagreeable, τοῖς ἀκούουσι Arist. Rh.Al. 1432b19: abs., ib. 1437a33.

children.label: III
children.definition: δ. ἐν τοῖς λόγοις to make difficulties in argument, to be captious, Pl. Grg. 450e.
disgust, Andronic.Rhod.p. 570 M., Plot. 1.9, Simp. in Epict. p.45 D.
one must boggle at, θεόν Pl. Lg. 828d, al.
peevish, M.Ant. 1.8, Hierocl. in CA 11p.444M. Adv. -κῶς, ζῆν Simp. in Epict. p.35 D.
harsh judgements, Pl. Phlb. 44d; inconveniences, Dam. Isid. 66:—condemned by Poll. 3.133.

children.label: I
children.definition: annoyance, disgust caused by a thing, τοῦ φορήματος, τοῦ νοσήματος, S. Ph. 473, 900, cf. Pl. Plt. 286b; unpleasantness, of food, D.C. 68.31: pl., Plu. QConv. 2.654b.

children.label: b
children.definition: odium, unpopularity, Pl. Lg. 967c (pl.).
difficulty, troublesome question, Id. R. 502d, Isoc. 5.12 (pl.), etc.; δ. παρέχειν Plb. 1.20.10; εἰς δ. ἐμπεσεῖν Id. 8.7.1; κατὰ τὴν προφοράν, opp. εὐχέρεια, Phld. Po. 994.8.
difficulties, δ. λογικαί Arist. Metaph. 1005b22, cf. 995a 33.

children.label: II
children.definition: harshness, Pl. Phlb. 44c; offensiveness, Thphr. Char. 19.
loathing, nausea, Pl. Prt. 334c.
hard to take in hand or manage, opp. εὐχερής:

children.label: I
children.definition: annoying, vexatious, θεωρία A. Pr. 802; πᾶσι θαῦμα δ. S. Ant. 254; Ἁρπάλου ἄφιξις Din. 2.5; of actions, odious, unpopular, Isoc. 12.63 ( Sup.); disagreeable, Pl. Lg. 779e ( Comp.); τὸ δ., = δυσχέρεια, E. Ph. 390; δυσχερὲς εἰπεῖν D. 18.3; δυσχερὲς ποιεῖσθαι to raise difficulties, Th. 4.85.
difficult, Pl. Hp.Mi. 369b ( Sup.), etc.; τύχη Lys. 24.6 ( Sup.); βίος D. 60.24; τὰ δυσχερῆ difficulties, Id. 10.58, al.; καιροὶ δ. difficult times, Inscr.Prien. 37.132.
contradictory, captious, Pl. Prt. 333d, D. 20.113; τὰ δυσχερῆ difficulties in an argument or discussion, Arist. EN 1145b6, Metaph. 1067b35.

children.label: II
children.definition: ill-tempered, unfriendly, τινί to one, S. El. 929; πρός τινα E. Ion 398; ἄτοποι καὶ δ. D. 19.308; δ. περὶ τὰ σιτία fastidious, Pl. R. 475c, cf. Arist. EE 1221b3.
unpleasant, offensive, Thphr. Char. 19.1; ὕδωρ D.C. 68.31.

children.label: III
children.definition: Adv. δυσχερῶς, φέρειν, Lat. aegre ferre, Hp. Aph. 1.25; ἀποδέχεσθαι Pl. Euthphr. 6a; δ. ἔχειν to be annoyed, πρός τι Id. Prt. 332a; ἐπί τινι Amphis 34.

troublesome, dangerous, fearful, δράκων A. Th. 503; πλημμυρίς Id. Ch. 186; κέλευθοι Id. Pers. 567 (lyr.); ὄρη Id. Fr. 342; χθών, πνεύματα, E. Ba. 15, Supp. 962 (lyr.). (It is doubtful whether - χῐμος (required by the metre in A.) is cognate with χεῖμα, hiems, cf. μελάγ-χῐμος: the form δύσχειμος is corrupt in A. Fr. 342, E.ll.cc.)
hard to split, Thphr. CP 5.16.4.
mean or shabby clothing, E. Hec. 240: in pl., τὰς ἐμὰς δυσχλαινίας Id. Hel. 416.
difficult to stage, Plu. QConv. 2.712e.
with little grass or food, δ. οἶκοι inhospitable dwellings, E. IT 219 (lyr.).

definition: δυσχραής δυσχερής, and δυσχρανής· αὐχμηρός, Hsch.

children.definition: to be intractable, Plb. 27.7.10.

children.label: II
children.definition: to be in difficulties or distress, Id. 4.60.8; ταῖς εἰρεσίαις Id. 16.4.10; διά τι Id. 1.51.6; περὶ τὴν ἔξοδον ib. 75.7:—also in Med., δ. ἐν τοῖς κινδύνοις ib. 87.7; πράγμασι, λόγοις, Id. 1.18.7, 3.11.4; of things, to be useless, Id. 16.3.5:— Pass., to be brought into distress, ἐπὶ τοῖς ἀπαντωμένοις ὑπʼ Ἀρχιμήδους Id. 8.6.5; to be annoyed, D.S. 18.39; ἐπί τινι Id. 19.77.
inconvenience, Stoic. 3.23.

difficult position, awkward circumstances, εἰς δ. ἥκειν Plb. 11.25.1, cf. 5.26.2, al.; distress, Phld. Ir. p.52 W., Mort. 26 (pl.); of things, inconvenience, disadvantage, Plb. 5.46.5: pl., Id. 1.53.13; χρείας καὶ δ. Str. 2.5.17; opp. πλεονέκτημα, Corn. ND 18, cf. Plu. Exil. 2.600a.

children.label: II
children.definition: χράω) difficulty in obtaining loans, ‘tightness’ of money, Cic. Att. 16.7.6.

hard to use, inconvenient, opp. εὔχρηστος, Hp. Aph. 2.54, cf. Sch. Il. Oxy. 221 vii 14; ἱππικὸν στράτευμα ἐν νυκτὶ . . δ. X. Cyr. 3.3.26; intractable, κύνες Id. Cyn. 3.11; of troops, Plb. 4.11.8 ( Sup.); δ. ἐξουσία hard to use well, Isoc. 8.103; δύσχρηστα inconveniences, Cic. Att. 7.5.3, cf. D.S. 4.8. Adv. - τως, διακεῖσθαι to be in difficulties, unmanageable, of ships, Plb. 1.61.4; of troops, ἀπαλλάττειν Id. 4.64.7; δ. ἔχειν Plu. Aem. 19:—synon. for οὐ χρησίμως, Str. 17.2.4.
bad colour, Dsc. Ther. 6, Gal. 17(2).215, Asp. in EN 44.6.

definition: δύσχροος, ον, contr. δύσ-χρους, ουν, = sq., Hp. Aph. 5.42.

children.definition: of a bad colour, discoloured, Hp. Coac. 136.
with bad juices, ill-savoured, Xenocr. 12.
an ill taste, Thphr. CP 6.12.12.
ill-savoured, Arist. GA 776a30, Thphr. CP 6.12.4.
hard to traverse: inextricable, ἀκρισία Plb. 23.1.13 (s. v. l.).

children.label: II
children.definition: difficult to digest, τροφή Aët. 9.30.
rough ground, X. Cyr. 1.6.35; τῶν Ἰταλῶν Jul. Or. 1.38c: in pl., X. Cyr. 1.4.7, Isoc. 6.80, Onos. 11.3, Gal. UP 3.1, etc.

children.label: II
children.definition: want of room, Ph. 2.563, Ath. 4.129c.

children.label: III
children.definition: difficulty, Alex.Aphr. Fat. 200.23.
hard to separate, Gal. 2.700 ( Comp.); hard to distinguish, ἡ κολακεία τῆς φιλίας δ. Plu. Adul. 2.51a.
not easily affected by cold, Gal. 1.346.
to be ill-smelling, Ph. 2.563.
ill-smelling, stinking, foul, χωλός, δ. S. Ph. 1032; δ. πῦον Hp. Prog. 7; καρπός Hdt. 2.94; πνεῦμα Th. 2.49; ὀσμαί Arist. HA 626a27: Comp., κόπρος Plu. Fr.inc. 149.
foul smell, Arist. Pol. 1311b34, HA 626b20, Ph. 2.96, Plu. Util. 2.90b, Phld. Herc. 19.27, etc.
causing grievous pangs, AP 6.272 ( Pers.).
hard to kill, tenacious of life, Thphr. HP 3.12.5.
hardly, i.e. reluctantly, swearing, Poll. 1.39.
beat down the price, cheapen, Pl.Com. 224:— Med., Arist. Fr. 558.
one who beats down the price, hard bargainer, Lync. ap. Ath. 6.228c; οὐδεὶς δ. χρηστὸν ὀψωνεῖ κρέας Com.Adesp. 277.
hard to buy, Hdn. Epim. 213.
have a bad name, Hdn. Epim. 203.

bearing an ill name, hateful, υἷες Ἀχαιῶν Il. 6.255; ἠώς Od. 19.571; μοῖρα Il. 12.116; λέκτρα S. OC 528 (lyr.); φθόνος E. Fr. 403; κήρ A.R. 2.258; esp. bearing a name of ill omen, such as αἴας, S. Aj. 914 (lyr.): Comp., Ph. 1.680:—in S. Fr. 88.9 (lyr.) perh. δ. γλώσσῃ whose tongue earned him an ill name (of Thersites).

definition: δυσωπέω, aor. ἐδυσώπησα Luc. Asin. 38: ( ὄψ):—

children.definition: put out of countenance, abash, τινά Ph. 1.291, Plu. Def.orac. 2.418e, Luc. l.c., S.E. P. 3.66, etc.; οὐδὲν αὐτὴν ἐδυσώπει X.Eph. 4.5: c. acc. inf., shame a person with doing a thing, J. BJ 1.6.5, al.: esp. of importunate persons, δ. τινὰ δεήσει ib. 3.8.6; so, entreat, ἥκειν ὑμᾶς καὶ παρακαλῶ καὶ δ. Hld. 10.2: abs., to be importunate, αἰσχυνόμενοι ἀντιλέγειν τοῖς ἀγνωμόνως δυσωποῦσιν ὕστερον δυσωποῦνται τοὺς δικαίως ἐγκαλοῦντας Plu. Vit.pud. 2.532d:— Pass., θεὸν εἶναι τὴν ἠχὼ δυσωποῦμαι I am constrained to believe that, Jul. Ep. 189, cf. Marcellin. Puls. 23; to be susceptible to importunity, τὴν ὑπὸ τῶν ἀναισχύντως λιπαρούντων ἧτταν, ἣν ἔνιοι δυσωπεῖσθαι καλοῦσιν Plu. Brut. 6; δυσωπεῖν τὴν ὄψιν to disgust, Id. Lyc. 9; alarm, πάθος δ. τινά Procop. Arc. 2.

data.quote: ἥκειν ὑμᾶς καὶ παρακαλῶ καὶ δ.
αἰσχυνόμενοι ἀντιλέγειν τοῖς ἀγνωμόνως δυσωποῦσιν ὕστερον δυσωποῦνται τοὺς δικαίως ἐγκαλοῦντας
τὴν ὑπὸ τῶν ἀναισχύντως λιπαρούντων ἧτταν, ἣν ἔνιοι δυσωπεῖσθαι καλοῦσιν

children.label: II
children.definition: Pass., impf. ἐδυσωπούμην Pl. Phdr. 242c:— to be put out of countenance, abs., Id. Plt. 285b, etc.; πρὸς ἀλλήλους Id. Lg. 933a; δ. μή . . Id. Phdr. l.c.; τινί Plb. 20.12.6; ἐπί τινι Ph. 1.639; εἰ . . Id. 2.423; περί τινος Phld. Rh. 1.297 S.; of animals, to be shy, timid, X. Mem. 2.1.4.

to be put to shame by, τὴν ἀρετήν τινος Plu. Cor. 15; τὴν χάριν Lib. Decl. 37.19: but more freq. fight shy of, ὄνομα D.H. Comp. 12 (so in Act., look askance at, δ. καὶ ὑποπτεύω μήποτʼ οὐ Λυσίου ὁ λόγος Id. Lys. 11), cf. Phryn. 166; ὑφορᾶν καὶ δ. Them. Or. 26.330b; διὰ τοὔνομα τὴν μοναρχίαν Plu. Sol. 14; regard with aversion, ὄψα Ael. Fr. 182; disapprove of, Phld. Hom. p.55 O.: c. inf., to be ashamed to do, . . εἰπεῖν D.Chr. 32.7, cf. 36.54; also τὴν ἀντίδοσιν δ. feel ashamed to reply, Jul. Ep. 184.

data.quote: δ. καὶ ὑποπτεύω μήποτʼ οὐ Λυσίου ὁ λόγος

children.label: III
children.definition: Act., to see with difficulty, Luc. Lex. 4.
a means of making one ashamed, and so, a corrective, τῶν ἡμαρτημένων J. BJ 1.25.5, cf. D.Chr. Fr. 8.
one must be shy of using, τὴν ταυτολογίαν Eust. 173.12.
importunate, Eust. 105.15 ( Comp.), etc. Adv. - κῶς Sch. Ar. Pl. 21 ( v.l. - ωπικῶς).

confusion of face, shamefacedness, Phld. Lib. p.24 O., Ph. 2.603 (pl.), Plu. Mult. 2.95b; false modesty, ib. Cupid. 528e, al.; cause for shame, ib. QConv. 707e, Cic. Att. 13.33.2; δυσωπίαν habere, to have an ugly look, ib. 16.15.2; τὰς δ. (v.l. δυστροπίας) τὰς ἐν τοῖς διαπορηθεῖσι dub. in Ph. 1.330.
keep painful watch, ὡς δὲ κύνες περὶ μῆλα δυσωρήσονται ἐν αὐλῇ Il. 10.183; but Apollon. Lex. read δυσωρήσωσιν, cf. Hsch., EM 292.49.

data.quote: ὡς δὲ κύνες περὶ μῆλα δυσωρήσονται ἐν αὐλῇ

children.definition: unseasonable, Poll. 5.109.
shrine (?), IG 4.823.42 ( Troezen), 7.2477 ( Cabireum).
diver, Hdt. 8.8; δ. βύθιος Poll. 1.97.
able to dive, ζῷον Arist. Fr. 496; ἡ -κή (sc. τέχνη) Poll. 7.139.

children.label: II
children.definition: δύσις) later form for δυσμικός, setting, Euc. Phaen. p.10 M.

western, στοά J. AJ 20.8.11; opp. ἀνατολικός, Ptol. Alm. 2.11: Comp. - ώτερος farther west, ib. 2.13; δ. ὠκεανός Nonn. D. 12.1; -κόν, τό, closing at sunset, = κλύμενον, Ps.- Dsc. 4.13; = φοῖνιξ, ib. 43.
water-bird, Dionys. Av. 2.13, 3.24.

children.label: A
children.definition: cause to sink, sink, plunge in; pres. only in Thphr. HP 5.4.8 οὐκ ἐν ἴσῳ βάθει πάντα δύοντες τῆς θαλάσσης: aor. 1 ἔδῡσα ( ἐξ-) Od. 14.341; cf. the compds. ἀπο-, ἐκ-, ἐν-, κατα-δύω.

children.label: B
children.definition: get or go into, c. acc.: pres. δύω (v. I.4); more freq. δύνω Il. 17.202, Hes. Op. 616, S. Ph. 1331, etc.; Ep. impf. δῦνον Il. 11.268: aor. ἔδῡνα Batr. 245, part. δύνας Plb. 9.15.9, Paus. 2.11.7, Ael. VH 4.1, but ἔδῡσα Ev.Marc. 1.32, etc.: more freq. Med. δύομαι Il. 5.140, E. Rh. 529 (lyr.), etc. (also in Att. Inscrr., as IG 2(2).1241): impf. ἐδυόμην Pl. Plt. 269a; Ep. δύοντο Il. 15.345: fut. δύσομαι [ῡ] 7.298, E. El. 1271: aor. ἐδῡσάμην A.R. 4.865, ( ἀπό) Nic. Al. 302; Ep. 3 pl. δύσαντο Il. 23.739, opt. δυσαίατο prob. in 18.376 (Prose and Com. in Compds.); Hom. mostly uses the Ep. forms ἐδύσεο, ἐδύσετο, imper. δύσεο 19.36, Hes. Sc. 108, part. δυσόμενος (in pres.sense) Od. 1.24, Hes. Op. 384: more freq. aor. ἔδυν (as if from *δῦμι) Il. 11.63, etc.; 3 dual ἐδύτην [ῡ] 10.254; 1 pl. ἔδῡμεν S. Fr. 367; ἔδῡτε Od. 24.106; ἔδῡσαν, Ep. ἔδυν Il. 11.263; Ion. 3 sg. δύσκεν 8.271; imper. δῦθι, δῦτε, 16.64, 18.140; subj. δύω [ῡ] 6.340, 22.99, but δύῃ [ῠ] Hes. Op. 728; Ep. opt. δύη [ῡ] (for δυίη) Od. 18.348; inf. δῦναι Il. 10.221, Att., Ep. δύμεναι [ῡ] 14.63, ἐκ-δῦμεν 16.99; part. δύς, δῦσα, Hdt. 8.8: pf. δέδῡκα Il. 5.811, Sapph. 52, Pl. Phd. 116e; Dor. inf. δεδυκεῖν [ῡ] Theoc. 1.102:— Pass., fut. and aor. δῠθήσομαι, ἐδύθην [ῠ], and a pf. δέδῠμαι only in compds., v. ἀποδύω, ἐκδύω, ἐνδύω. [ῠ in δύω in pres. and impf. Act. and Med., Hom.; but A.R. has δῡομαι, δῡετο 1.581, part. δῡόμενος ib. 925, Call. Epigr. 22; δῡεται Nonn. D. 7.286; ἐκ-δέδῠκας AP 5.72 ( Rufin.).]

children.label: I
children.definition: enter, make oneʼs way into, in Hom. the most freq. use, εἰ . . κε πύλας καὶ τείχεα δύω ( aor. 2) Il. 22.99; πόλιν δύσεσθαι Od. 7.18; ἔδυ νέφεα plunged into the clouds, of a star, Il. 11.63; δῦτε θαλάσσης εὐρέα κόλπον plunge into the lap of Ocean, 18.140; γαῖαν ἐδύτην went beneath the earth, i.e. died, 6.19, cf. 411, etc.; πόλεμον δύμεναι plunge into . . , 14.63; θεῖον δύσονται ἀγῶνα 7.298; ἐδύσετο οὐλαμὸν ἀνδρῶν 20.379; δύσεο δὲ μνηστῆρας go in to them, Od. 17.276; rarely in Trag., αἰθέρα δ. S. Aj. 1192 (lyr.), cf. E. El. 1271.

Ep. less freq. with Preps., ἔδυν δόμον Ἄϊδος εἴσω Il. 11.263; δύσομαι εἰς Ἀΐδαο Od. 12.383; ἐς πόντον ἐδύσετο 5.352; δέρτρον ἔσω δύνοντες 11.579; δύσεθʼ ἁλὸς κατὰ κῦμα Il. 6.136; ὑπὸ κῦμα θαλάσσης αὐτίκʼ ἔδυσαν 18.145; κατὰ σταθμοὺς δύεται slinks into the fold, 5.140; καθʼ ὅμιλον ἔδυ Τρώων 3.36 (rarely c. gen., κατὰ σπείους κοίλοιο δέδυκεν Od. 12.93); πάϊς ὣς ὑπὸ μητέρα δύσκεν εἰς Αἴαντα he got himself unto Ajax, i.e. got behind his shield, Il. 8.271; βέλος δʼ εἰς ἐγκέφαλον δῦ ib. 85; ἀκίδες δεδυκυῖαι διὰ φλεβῶν Plu. Crass. 25; in Prose and Trag. mostly with a Prep. (but δυόμενοι abs., diving, Th. 7.25), δῦναι ἐς θάλασσαν Hdt. 8.8; ἐς ἄντρον A. Fr. 261; ἁρμὸν . . πρὸς αὐτὸ στόμιον S. Ant. 1217; κατὰ βάθος Pl. Lg. 905a; κατὰ τῆς γῆς Id. Phd. 113c, etc.
εἴσω ἔδυ ξίφος the sword entered his body, Il. 16.340; δύνει ἀλοιφή sinks in (where however βοείην may be supplied), 17.392:— Med., δύου πάλιν Ar. V. 148.

sink into [the sea], set, ἠέλιος μὲν ἔδυ Il. 18.241, cf. Od. 3.329, etc.; ἔδυ φάος ἠελίοιο 13.35; δύσετό τʼ ἠέλιος 2.388, cf. Il. 7.465, etc.; ἀελίω δύντος Sapph. 96.8 L.-P.; so Βοώτης ὀψὲ δύων late- setting Boötes, Od. 5.272; δείελος ὀψὲ δύων Il. 21.232; [ σελαναία] δύεν Bion Fr. 8.6; πρὸ δύντος ἡλίου Hdt. 7.149; πρὸ ἡλίου δύντος D. 15.22; δυσόμενος Ὑπερίων (to mark the West) Od. 1.24; ἐδύετο εἰς τόπον [ὁ ἥλιος] Pl. Plt. 269a; πρὸς δύνοντος ἡλίου towards the West, A. Supp. 255: metaph., βίου δύντος αὐγαί Id. Ag. 1123 (lyr.); ἔδυ πρόπας δόμος ib. 1011 (lyr.); δεδυκὸς ζῆν live in retirement, Pl. Lg. 781c.

children.label: II
children.definition: get into, Ἀρήϊα τεύχεα δ. Il. 6.340, etc.; κυνέην δ. put on oneʼs helmet, 5.845; δῦ δὲ χιτῶνʼ 18.416: metaph., εἰ μὴ σύ γε δύσεαι ἀλκήν if thou wilt not put on strength, 9.231; so ἀνάγκας ἔδυ λέπαδνον A. Ag. 218 (lyr.): hence,
put on, ἀμφʼ ὤμοισιν ἐδύσετο τεύχεα Il. 3.328, etc.; ὤμοιϊν . . τεύχεα δῦθι 16.64; χιτῶνα περὶ χροΐ . . δῦνεν Od. 15.61; χρυσὸν . . ἔδυνε περὶ χροΐ Il. 8.43.
ὅπλοισιν ἔνι δεινοῖσιν ἐδύτην 10.272, cf. A.R. 1.638; ἐς τεύχεα δύντε Od. 22.201.

children.label: III
children.definition: enter, come over or upon, κάματος . . γυῖα δέδυκεν Il. 5.811; ὄφρʼ ἔτι μᾶλλον δύη ἄχος κραδίην Od. 18.348; ἦτορ δῦνʼ ἄχος Il. 19.367; ὀδύναι δῦνον μένος 11.272; κρατερὴ δέ ἑ λύσσα δέδυκε madness is come over him, 9.239; δῦ μιν Ἄρης Ares, i.e. the spirit of war, filled him, 17.210; μιν ἔδυ χόλος 19.16.

data.quote: ὄφρʼ ἔτι μᾶλλον δύη ἄχος κραδίην

children.definition: weighing two obols Gal. 13.92, al.

definition: δυώδεκα, Ion., Ep., Lyr.; Att. δώδεκα,

children.definition: twelve, in all genders, Il. 2.637, Hdt. 1.16, Pi. N. 4.28, etc.; οἱ δώδεκα θεοί Aeschin.Socr. 5, Com.Adesp. 39.9 D.:—also δυόδεκο, IG 5(2).3 ( Tegea, iv B.C.).
worth twelve oxen, Il. 23.703.
belonging to the δυωδεκάς I, Dam. Pr. 276.
running the course twelve times, τέθριππα Pi. O. 2.50.
Leg.Gort. 12.34.

definition: δυωδεκαΐς, ίδος, Att.; Ion. δωδεκηΐς, ίδος, and δωδεκ-ῄς, - ῇδος, ἡ,

children.definition: sacrifice of twelve victims, SIG 2438 D 37 (Delph.), SIG 3604.9 ( Delph., ii B.C.), Porph. Abst. 1.22, etc.: as Adj., θυσίαι Eust. 1386.48: hence name of a sacred mission to Delphi, SIG 773.2 (i B.C.).
divided into twelve parts, AP 7.641 ( Antiphil.).
of twelve cubits, εὖρος Opp. H. 2.143.
twelvefold, IG 14.644 (Brutt.).
formed of twelve united states, Ἴωνες Hdt. 7.95.
the number twelve, Procl. in Euc. p.174 F.; group of twelve divinities, Dam. Pr. 348.

children.label: II
children.definition: twelfth part, of the signs of the zodiac, Arat. 555 (pl.), 703; of an hour, AP 9.779, 782 ( Paul.Sil.).
having twelve walled cities, λαός Tim. Pers. 247.
twelfth month, IG 14.425 iv, 427 ii ( Tauromenium).
holding twenty-two measures, τρίπους Il. 23.264.
twenty-two cubits long, 15.678.

definition: δῶ, τό, shortd. Ep. form for δῶμα,

children.definition: house, dwelling, Hom. only in nom. as Od. 1.392, and acc. as Il. 1.426.—As pl. for δώματα, only in Hes. Th. 933.
twelve times victorious in the Actian games, BGU 1074.23 (iii A. D.).
of twelve oxen, θυσία IGRom. 4.555 ( Ancyra).
with twelve altars, ναός Lyd. Mens. 4.2.
bent twelve times, τέρμα the post (in the race-course) that has been doubled twelve times, Pi. O. 3.33.
dodecagon, Plu. Isid. 2.363a.
twelve fingers long or broad, Apollod. Poliorc. 178.3; of twelve digits, of the apparent diameter of sun and moon, Cleom. 2.3; δ. ἔκφυσις the duodenum, Herophil. ap. Gal. 2.572, Ruf. Anat. 42.
leader of twelve, X. Cyr. 3.3.11; codd. have - δεκάρχας, - δεκαδάρχας in ib. 2.4.4.
sold at twelve drachmae, οἶνος D. 42.20.

children.label: II
children.definition: privileged to pay as poll-tax only twelve dr., POxy. 258.8 (i A.D.), al.
twelve palms long, κέρα AP 6.96 ( Eryc.).
with twelve surfaces: δωδεκάεδρον, τό, dodecahedron, Euc. 11 Def. 28, 13.17, Arist. Cael. 307a16.
conqueror in twelve contests, Sammelb. 2134.4, APl. 16.99 (also δύω- Nonn. D. 35.335).
cycle of twelve years, τοῦ Διός Gp. 1.12 tit.: pl., title of Orphic work, Suid.

definition: δωδεκαετής, ές, or δωδεκᾰ-έτης, ες, ( ἔτος)

children.definition: lasting twelve years, χρόνος J. AJ 15.9.6.

children.label: II
children.definition: twelve years old, Plu. Comp.Lyc.Num. 4, Apophth.reg. 2.198c.
space of twelve years, Ptol. Tetr. 206; ὑπὲρ τῆς δ., title of a speech of Demades.

children.label: II
children.definition: age of twelve years, BGU 592i3 (ii A. D.).
having twelve signs, οὐρανός Lyd. Mens. 4.67.
of twelve days, Eust. 128.13.
of twelve Gods, cena, Suet. Aug. 70.

children.label: II
children.definition: Subst. - θεον, τό, temple of the twelve Gods, Inscr.Cos 43.
medicine compounded of twelve ingredients, Paul.Aeg. 7.11.
primrose, Primula acaulis. Plin. HN 25.28.
twelve times, Ar. Pl. 852, Arist. Fr. 347, D.C. 60.7, etc.
holding twelve κλῖναι, Anaxandr. 41.11.
with twelve springs, Cratin. 186, Philostr. VS 1.22.4.
of twelve clauses, Sch. Ar. Eq. 821.
of twelve threads, X. Cyn. 2.5.
of twelve months, τέλος Pi. N. 11.10 (but δυω- codd.): - μηνον, τό, year, Thd. Da. 4.26, POxy. 506.15 (ii A.D.):—poet. δυωδεκάμ-, twelve months old, Hes. Op. 752.
knowing twelve arts or tricks, ἄστρον E. Fr. 755 (lyr.); of a courtesan, Ar. Ra. 1327 (et Sch.), cf. Pl.Com. 134.
weighing twelve minae, Hsch. s.v. πέλεκυς.
of twelve forms, Olymp. in Phd. p.199 N.
of twelve labours, epith. of Heracles, Lyd. Mens. 4.67.
of twelve fathoms, Hero *Geom. 4.12.
with twelve children, λοχείη APl. 16.132 ( Theodorid.).
twelve times πάλαι, ever so long ago, Ar. Eq. 1154; cf. δεκάπαλαι, μυριόπαλαι.
twelve cubits high, κολοσσοί Hdt. 2.153 ( δυω-) ; σιρός Anaxandr. 41.28, cf. BCH 35.243 ( Delos, ii B. C.), Philostr. VA 4.16.
multiply by twelve, Heph.Astr. 2.2.
multiplication by twelve, Cat.Cod.Astr. 4.44.
twelvefold, Plu. An.procr. 2.1028c; also δωδεκα-πλᾰσίων, ον, gen. ονος, Orib. Fr. 102.
twelve-sided figure, v.l. in Gal. Anim.Pass. 2.3.
Papp. 609.

definition: δωδεκάπους, ὁ, ἡ, πουν, τό, gen. ποδος,

children.definition: twelve feet long, Men. 364, Gal. 10.33.
δωδεκά-αρχος, Hsch. s.v. δεκαδάρχαι.
group of twelve, Pl. Lg. 756b.

children.label: II
children.definition: Hsch. (pl.).
having twelve moons, ἐνιαυτός Sch. E. Tr. 1075.
of twelve times, in music, Aristid. Quint. 1.14, Sch. Ar. Nu. 456 cod. Ven.
twelve-oared, Plu. Caes. 38.
of twelve strips of leather, σφαῖρα Pl. Phd. 110b, Plu. QPlat. 2.1003d.
twelve stades long, etc., Posidon. 18 J., Str. 13.1.36.
weighing twelve times as much, Pl. Hipparch. 231d.
with twelve stories, πύργος Ps.-Callisth. 2.18.
colonnade of twelve columns, Milet. 7.59 ( Didyma).
of twelve syllables, Ἀλκαϊκὸν δ. (sc. μέτρον) Heph. 10.3, 14.4.

definition: δωδεκάσχοινος, ἡ, name of a district in Egypt, OGI 210.5, 670.5, Ptol. Geog. 4.5.74.

children.definition: on the twelfth day, in twelve days, δ. ἀνεβίω Pl. R. 614b, cf. Thphr. HP 7.1.3; δυωδεκαταῖος ἀφʼ ὧτέ νιν οὐδὲ ποτεῖδον Theoc. 2.157.

data.quote: δυωδεκαταῖος ἀφʼ ὧτέ νιν οὐδὲ ποτεῖδον

children.label: II
children.definition: twelve days old, Hes. Op. 751 (in poet. form δυωδ-), Arist. HA 567a5.
twelfth part, [ χώρας] Pl. Lg. 848c, cf. IG 12(7).237.56 ( Amorgos, ii/i B. C.), Ph. 1.673; sign of the zodiac, Hipparch. 2.1.7, Ptol. Tetr. 93, etc.
Man. 4.167:—also δωδεκα-τήμορος, ον, PHib. 1.27.122 (iv/iii B.C.).
twelfth, Il. 24.781, etc.; δ. τόκοι, 8 1/3%, SIG 364.74 ( Ephesus, iii B. C.), etc.:— Ep. δυωδ-, Il. 1.493, etc.

children.label: II
children.definition: δωδεκάτη, ἡ, = Χόες, Hsch.
fixed circle of twelve divisions through which the zodiac is supposed to revolve, Vett.Val. 179.33, Cat.Cod.Astr. 5 (3).89, al.
bearing twelve times a year, Luc. VH 2.13.
with twelve petals, ῥόδα δ. Thphr. HP 6.6.4.

children.label: II
children.definition: with twelve leaves, κλάδος PMag.Berol. 2.67.
of twelve tribes, τὸ δ. the twelve tribes of Israel, Act.Ap. 26.7.
with twelve strings, ὄργανον EM 813.43.
in twelve ways, An.Ox. 2.3. ( Theognost.).
holding twelve χόες, PRev.Laws 40.11 (iii B. C.), al.
of twelve hours, Secund. Sent. 4, S.E. M. 10.182.

children.label: II
children.definition: δωδεκάωρος, ἡ, circle of twelve animal figures typifying the double hours of the Chaldaean νυχθήμερον, Teucer in Cat.Cod.Astr. 7.195, al.

definition: δωδεκέμβριος, ὁ, = Dodecember, month invented by Licinus, D.C. 54.21.

children.definition: twelve years old, Call. Epigr. 21 ( δωδεκένη Meineke), Plu. Aem. 35:—in form δωδεχέτης, IG 4.51 ( Aegina), Annuario 4/5.467 ( Halic., iv B.C.):—fem. δωδεκ-έτις, ιδος, AP 11.70 ( Leon.).
which held twelve cotylae, Hsch.
period of twelve days, IG 1(2).374.89.
a ship with twelve banks of oars, Callix. 1.
with twelve knobs, πόπανον IG 2(2).1367.

Dodona, in Epirus, the seat of the most ancient oracle of Zeus, Il. 16.234, Od. 14.327, Hes. Fr. 134, 212, A. Pr. 830, etc.: heterocl. forms Δωδῶνος, -ῶνι (as if from Δωδών), S. Fr. 460, Tr. 172: Δωδώνᾱθεν Pi. N. 4.53; Δωδώνηθε Call. Del. 284: a nom. Δωδώ, Simm. ap. Str. 8.5.3.:— Adj. Δωδωναῖος, α, ον, Il. 16.233, A. Supp. 258, Cratin. 5.: prov., Δωδωναῖον χαλκεῖον chatterbox, Eust. 335.45:—fem. Δωδωνίς, ίδος, S. Fr. 456, Hdt. 2.53, Pherecyd. 90 J.

definition: δωλέννετος ὑπόβλητος, Hsch.; cf. sq. [δωλοδομεῖς, δῶλος]
δωλοδομεῖς οἰκογενεῖς, Hsch. (cf. δοῦλος and ἐβάθη· ἐγεννήθη, Id.: Lith. giṁti ‘to be bornʼ).

children.definition: Leg.Gort. 1.1, al.; voc. δῶλε Theoc. 5.5.: but δῶλα· ὦτα (Cret.), Hsch.

house, πατρώϊον ἵκετο δ. Il. 21.44, etc.; mainly poet., but once in Hdt., 2.62 (pl.), and in late Prose (v. infr.), but never in Att. Prose: also, chief room, hall, θάλαμον καὶ δ. καὶ αὐλήν Il. 6.316, cf. Od. 17.329, al.: hence, pl. for a single house, 2.259, freq. in Trag., A. Ag. 607, S. Tr. 332, E. Or. 301, etc.

ἀθάνατοι Ὀλύμπια δώματʼ ἔχοντες Il. 2.13, etc.; κλυτὰ δ. βένθεσι λίμνης, of Poseidon, 13.21; freq. of Pluto, δῶμʼ Ἀΐδαο the nether world, Od. 12.21; ὦ δῶμʼ Ἀΐδου καὶ Περσεφόνης S. El. 110; Πλούτωνος δ. E. HF 808 (lyr.); of a temple, Pi. P. 4.53, A. Eu. 242, etc.: pl., Hdt. 2.62, S. OT 71.
δῶμα Καδμεῖον, i.e. Thebes, ib. 29.
housetop, LXX De. 22.8, Ev.Matt. 24.17, Babr. 5.5, POxy. 475.22 (ii A.D.), etc.

children.label: II
children.definition: household, family, A. Ag. 1468 (lyr.), S. OT 1226, etc.; cf. δῶ.
Dim. of δῶμα, Ar. Ra. 100, IG 12(8).442.8 ( Thasos), Jul. ad Them. 263a [5 fin., 6 fin.,..].

children.label: II
children.definition: chamber, bedchamber, Ar. Lys. 160, Lys. 1.17, 24, Pl. R. 390c, and so prob. in X.Eph. 2.1, Procop. Arc. 23.

children.label: III
children.definition: housetop (cf. foreg. [δῶμα] I.4), J. BJ 2.21.5, Hdn. 1.12.8.
of, belonging to the house, Ποσειδῶν Paus. 3.14.7, IG 5(1).497, al. ( Sparta); Ἀπόλλων Sch. Pi. N. 5.81: fem., δωματῖτις ἑστία A. Ag. 968.
have a house built for one, to be housed, δεδωμάτωμαι οὐ σμικρᾷ χερί A. Supp. 958.
ruin the house, cj. for σωματοφθ-, A. Ag. 948.

build, A.R. 2.531, IG 14.1868, AP 7.142:—more freq. in Med., ib. 11.400 ( Luc.), Coluth. 287, Orph. A. 570: metaph., build up, restore to life, τινά Lyc. 48:— Pass., δ. ἐκ λίθων Antyll. ap. Orib. 9.13.6; of a statue, to be set up, App.Anth. 2.534 (Halic.).
chamber, δω[μ]ήματι τύμβου Benndorf-Niemann Reisen in Lykien p.80 No.59 ( Sidyma).

definition: δώμησις, εως, ἡ, and δωμ-ητύς, ύος, ἡ,

children.definition: building, Hsch.
builder, Man. 6.415.

definition: δωμός, Dor. for ζωμός, Epil. 3 (prob. l.), EM 316.56.

children.definition: = Lat. duracinum, a kind of peach, clingstone, Gp. 3.1.4, 10.13.1.

definition: δωρεά, Ion. δωρ-εή, ἡ: δωρειά in earlier Attic Inscrr., IG 1(2).77, al., δωρεά first in ib. 2(2).1.68:—

children.definition: gift, present, esp. bounty ( = δόσις ἀναπόδοτος Arist. Top. 125a18), Hdt. 2.140; δωρεὰν διδόναι Id. 6.130, A. Pr. 340; πορεῖν ib. 616; δωρεῖσθαι Pl. Plt. 290c; δ. δέχεσθαι, λαμβάνειν, Isoc. 6.31, 15.40; ironically, θάνατόν τινι δωρεὰν ἀποδοῦναι Antipho 5.34; δ. ἔχειν S. Aj. 1032, D. 18.312; ἐν χάριτος μέρει καὶ δωρειᾶς D. 21.165; δωρειὰν καὶ χάριν ib. 172, cf. Pl. Lg. 844d; of a legacy, D. 27.41, 65; δωρεαί privileges and immunities, opp. δῶρα, gifts in cash or kind, Philostr. VS 2.10.4.
estate granted by a king, fief, Phoenicid. 4.7, PSI 5.511.4, 518.2 (iii B.C.).

children.label: II
children.definition: δωρεάν as Adv., as a free gift, freely, Hdt. 5.23, prob. in And. 1.4; μηδὲν δ. πράττειν Plb. 18.34.7, cf. LXX Jb. 1.9; δ. λειτουργεῖν Test.Epict. 4.27, cf. Inscr.Prien. 4.17 (iv B.C.); so κατὰ δωρεάν IG 7.2711.13, al. ( Acraeph., i A. D.); ἐν δωρεᾷ προσνεῖμαι Plb. 22.5.4; but γῆν ( ἀμπελῶνα, etc.) ἐν δωρεᾷ ἔχειν to hold land by a royal grant, PRev.Laws 36.15 (iii B.C.), cf. 43.11, 44.3.
to no purpose, for naught, Ep.Gal. 2.21.
held by royal grant, γῆ Sammelb. 1178a, 1178b, cf. 3937, 3938 (iii B. C.); v. foreg. II.
concerning grants, γράμμα PMasp. 13.26 (vi A. D.).
= foreg., ὁμολογία Sammelb. 4678.13 (vi A. D.).

definition: δωρέω, fut. - ήσω Hom. Fr. 17: aor. ἐδώρησα Hes. Op. 82, Pi. O. 6.78:—

children.definition: give, present, δῶρον Hes. l.c.; present one with, θυσίαις Ἑρμᾶν Pi. l.c.:— Pass., aor. δωρηθῆναι to be given or presented, Hdt. 1.87, Isoc. 4.26: in pf. Pass., παρὰ θεῶν δῶρα ὑμῖν δεδώρηται Pl. Plt. 274c; and of persons, to be presented with a thing, χώρῃ Hdt. 8.85, cf. S. Aj. 1029.

children.label: II
children.definition: Med. δωρέομαι, ῥεῖα θεὸς . . ἵππους δωρήσαιτʼ Il. 10.557; δωρέεσθαί τί τινι present a thing to one, Hdt. 2.126, 5.37, A. Pr. 253, X. An. 7.3.20, etc.; σπέρμα εἰς Πελοπόννησον δωρήσασθε Id. HG 6.3.6; also δ. τινά τινι present one with a thing, Hdt. 1.54, 3.130, A. Pr. 778; δ. τινά to make him presents, Hdt. 1.55: pf., δεδώρηται Pl. Ti. 46e, Lg. 672b, X. Cyr. [5.2.8].
pres. and impf. also, offer, E. Supp. 875.
gift, present, Hdt. 7.38, etc.: c. dat. pers., A. Pers. 523, Eu. 402, S. Tr. 668: pl., E. Or. 123, etc.—Rare in Prose, X. Hier. 8.4, Arist. EN 1099b11, and later, Ph. 2.9, Ep.Jac. 1.17.
giver, AP 6.305 ( Leon.).
benefactor, IG 12(2).645b64 ( Nesus, iv B. C.).
concerned with giving, Pl. Sph. 223c.

children.label: II
children.definition: munificent, Ph. 1.254.
open to gifts or presents, Il. 9.526.

children.label: II
children.definition: freely given, δ., οὐκ αἰτητόν S. OT 384, cf. Plu. Cor. 16.
dress like a Dorian girl, i.e. in a single garment open at the side, Anacr. 59.

children.label: II
children.definition: Anacreont. 10.6, Philostr. VS 1.24.2.

definition: Δωριακός, ή, όν, poet. for Δωρικός, πόλεμος Orac. ap. Th. 2.54.

children.definition: to be archon of the Dorians, SIG 668.12 ( Delph., ii B. C.), 770B2 ( Delph., i B. C.).
festival at Cnidus, GDI 4271 ( Cedreae):—also Δώρεια, ib. 3660 ( Cos).
Dorian, descendant of Dorus son of Hellen, IG 12(5).225 ( Paros): pl., Δωριεῖς, Ion. - ιέες, Att. - ιῆς, οἱ, the Dorians, Od. 19.177, etc.

children.label: II
children.definition: Adj., = Δωρικός, Pi. P. 8.20.
imitate the Dorians in life, dialect, etc., speak Doric Greek, Theoc. 15.93, Str. 8.1.2, Plu. Def.orac. 2.421b:— Pass., to be written in the Doric dialect, δ. τὰ Ἀλκμᾶνος A.D. Synt. 279.25.
Doric, Hdt. 8.43, Th. 3.95, etc.: Comp. - ώτερος A.D. Adv. 159.27. Adv. -κῶς Id. Pron. 48.27, S.E. M. 1.78: Comp. - ώτερον A.D. Synt. 159.16.

definition: Δώριος, α, ον, also ος, ον Pratin.Lyr. 1.17, Arist. Pol. 1276b9: —

children.definition: Dorian, Pi. O. 3.5; ἁπλοῦν τε καὶ Δ. Plu. Lys. 5, etc.; esp. of the Dorian mode in music, Arist. Pol. l.c., 1290a22.
Adj. Dorian, ἐσθής Hdt. 5.88; φωνή Th. 6.5, etc.: hence,
Δ. νᾶσος the Dorian island, of Aegina and Peloponnesus, Pi. N. 3.3, S. OC 696 (lyr.), etc.
γῆ) Doris, in Northern Greece, Hdt. 8.31, Plu. Them. 9, etc.
Δ. κόρα a Dorian damsel, E. Hec. 934 (lyr.).
κοπίς) Dorian knife used at sacrifices, Id. El. 819.
Δωρίς, = ἔχιον, Dsc. 4.27.

children.label: b
children.definition: Dsc. 3.96 (also δωριπτερίς ibid.).
speaking in the Doric dialect, Demetr. Eloc. 177.
in Dorian fashion, Δ. ζῆν Pl. Ep. 336c.
in the Dorian dialect, λαλοῦσι Δ. Call. Iamb. 1.354.

children.label: II
children.definition: ἡ Δ. ἁρμονία the Dorian mode or measure in music, Arist. Pol. 1340b4; so Δ. alone, Pl. R. 399a; in Ar. Eq. 989 (lyr.) with a play on δῶρον.
in which the conqueror received a present, Plu. Praec. 2.820d.

definition: δωρογραφία, ἡ, dub. sens. in Ostr.Strassb. 277.11, al. (ii A.D.).

children.definition: giving dinner, παῖς δ., i.e. a waiter, Ath. 15.701b.
one that takes bribes, LXX Jb. 15.34.
accept as a present, esp. take as a bribe, ἀργύριον πολλόν Hdt. 6.72; χρυσόν Pl. R. 590a; κατὰ πεντήκοντα τάλαντα Ar. V. 669.
take bribes, Hdt. 6.82, D. 18.45, etc.; ἐπί τινι Lys. 21.22, D. 18.49.

children.label: II
children.definition: δωροδοκοῦσιν is f.l. in Ar. V. 675 and δωροδοκοῦντας (abs.) is interpol. in D. 9.45), corrupt by bribes, D.S. 13.64, Arr. Epict. 4.1.148, Luc. Pisc. 9, etc.
bestow gifts, AP 9.335 ( Leon.): c. acc., ib. 12.204 ( Strat.).

children.label: III
children.definition: Pass., of persons, to have a bribe given one, Cratin. 128, cf. Plb. 6.56.2, D.H. 4.55 (as v.l.); also ταῦθʼ ἁπλῶς δεδωροδόκηται this has been accomplished by bribery, D. 19.329 ( v.l. - ηνται) ; τὰ περὶ τὴν Εὔβοιαν δωροδοκηθέντα the bribery in the matter of Euboea, Aeschin. 3.221; τὸ δεδωροδοκημένον χρυσίον Din. 1.66.
acceptance of a bribe, corruption, D. 18.20,31.
bribe, καταλαβεῖν Pl.Com. 119.
taking of bribes, freq. in Oratt., as And. 4.30; δωροδοκίαν καταγνῶναί τινος Lys. 21.21; -ίας κατηγορεῖν Aeschin. 2.3: pl., ibid.; also, giving of bribes, corruption, in pl., D.C. 39.55, 50.7.
in bribe-fashion, Ar. Eq. 996, with a play on Δωριστί.
taking presents or bribes, corrupt, Pl. R. 390d, D. 18.61; Com., δωροδόκοισιν ἐπʼ ἄνθεσιν ἵζων Ar. Eq. 403.

children.label: II
children.definition: Act., bribing, Sch. Pl. Alc. 2.149a, cf. AB 242.
munificent, Aret. SD 2.12.
give presents, Aq. Ez. 16.33.
giver of presents, λάθας δ. AP 12.49 ( Mel.).
receptacle for offerings, alms-box, Zonar. s.v. Κορβωνᾶς.
bribe, LXX Si. 32(35).12:— Pass., ib. 3 Ma. 4.19.
one who bribes, Gloss.
take presents, Eust. 91.17.
greedy of gain, LXX Pr. 15.27.
taking of presents, Com.Adesp. 987, D.C. 39.55.

gift, present, gift of honour, ἀγλαὰ δ. Il. 1.213, etc.; votive gift or offering to a god, φέρε δῶρον Ἀθήνῃ 6.293, cf. LXX Ge. 4.4, Ev.Marc. 7.11; βωμοὶ δώροισι φλέγονται A. Ag. 91; ποῦ μοι τὰ . . δ. κἀκροθίνια; Id. Fr. 184; δῶρά τινος the gifts of, i.e. given by, him, θεῶν ἐρικυδέα δ. Il. 20.265, cf. Od. 18.142; δῶρʼ Ἀφροδίτης, i.e. personal charms, Il. 3.54, 64; δ. Κύπριδος E. Hel. 363 (lyr.); δ. τῶν Μουσῶν καὶ Ἀπόλλωνος, of μουσική, Pl. Lg. 796e: c. gen. rei, ὕπνου δ. the blessing of sleep, Il. 7.482; δῶρα presents given as tribute, 17.225; δῶρον τοῦ ποταμοῦ, of the land of Egypt, Hdt. 2.5.

δῶρα presents, as retaining fees or bribes, D. 18.109, Jusj.ib. 24.150, Arist. Ath. 55.5, SIG 953.7 ( Calymna), etc. (the usual sense of the word in Att. Oratt.): hence in Att. law, δώρων γραφή an indictment for being bribed, Aeschin. 3.232, etc., cf. Harp.; δώρων κριθῆναι to be tried for taking bribes, Lys. 27.3; δώρων ἑλεῖν τινα to convict him of taking bribes, Ar. Nu. 591; δ. ὀφλεῖν to be found guilty of taking bribes, And. 1.74; δώρων δίωξις Plu. Per. 32.
good qualities, talents, τὰ βασιλέως δ. Lib. Ep. 19.

children.label: II
children.definition: front part of palm, Poll. 2.144.
handʼs breadth, palm, as a measure of length, Nic. Th. 398, Vitr. 2.3.3, Milet. 7.57 ( Didyma); cf. δεκάδωρος.
indictment of a ξένος for bribing the judges to declare him an Athenian, Lys. Fr. 196 S., Hyp. Fr. 20, Arist. Ath. 59.3.
bring presents, Orac. ap. D. 43.66.
devouring gifts, greedy of presents, Hes. Op. 221, 264, Plb. 6.9.7.
bring presents, τινί Pl. Phdr. 266c, cf. Euthphr. 14e, prob. in Epigr. ap. Ath. 5.209e ( Archimelos); give as presents or bribes, τί τινι Ar. V. 675, cf. D.C. 40.53.

children.label: II
children.definition: δ. τινά present him with gifts, Ael. VH 1.32.
bringing of presents, v.l. in Ep.Rom. 15.31, Alciphr. 1.6 (pl.), Poll. 4.47.

definition: δωροφορικός, ή, όν, = sq., Pl. Sph. 222d.

children.label: II
children.definition: given as a present, στολή Ael. VH 1.22.
bringing presents, Pi. P. 5.86, f.l. in Epigr. ap. Ath. 5.209e ( Archimelos); tributary, Euph. 78.
Hes. Op. 356.
life-giving, Mus. Belg. 16.70.
administration of justice, IGRom. 3.563 ( Tlos).
referring disputes to a court, Hdt. 6.42.
subject to jurisdiction, δ. παρασχεῖν τοὺς ἠδικηκότας Plb. 4.4.3, cf. UPZ 121.14.
Suid. s.v. ἀφέλεια.

definition: Δώσων, οντος, ὁ, fut. part. of δίδωμι,

children.definition: always going to give, always promising: hence Δώσων as a name of Antigonus II, Plu. Cor. 11.

definition: δώτειρα, ἡ, fem. of sq., Linus ap. Stob. 3.1.70, Arat. 113, Man. 2.447, Nonn. D. 19.45.

children.definition: giver, δωτῆρες ἑάων givers of good, i.e. the gods, Od. 8.325, Hes. Th. 46, etc.: voc. δῶτερ ὑγείης Rev.Arch. 1911.439 ( Thrace).

definition: δώτης, ου, ὁ, = foreg., Hes. Op. 355.

children.definition: receive or collect presents, Hdt. 2.180.
gift, present, Il. 9.155, Od. 9.268, Hdt. 1.61; δωτίνην δοῦναι give as a free gift, ib. 69, cf. Them. Or. 21.260d.

children.label: II
children.definition: rent in kind, IG 4.841.8,11 ( Calauria, iii B.C.).
Suid. (leg. ἐδητύς).

definition: Δωτώ, οῦς, ἡ, Giver, name of a Nereid, Il. 18.43, Hes. Th. 248.

children.definition: giver of goods, addressed to Hermes, Od. 8.335, h.Hom. 18.12, cf. Luc. Sat. 14; to Zeus, Call. Jov. 91; θεοὶ τούτων δώτορες ἀμφοτέρων Thgn. 134, cf. E. Hyps.Fr. 7.5.
